Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance. For several months we have been working with the Conservative member for Calgary North, who proposed a new federal tax strategy for families. His proposals are a response to concerns expressed by families, family and religious organizations and federal members. Could the

February 6, 1992
Oral Questions
minister give us the assurance that his department will give careful consideration-before the budget-to this new strategy that would help improve the financial situation of married couples with children and that of single parent families in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister was extremely concerned about family issues and a family caucus was organized within our government, led by the member for Calgary North who has done an excellent job. He has made certain suggestions to the Minister of Finance which I can assure all members of the House will be given very careful consideration for the upcoming budget.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport. Polls released today indicate that 85 per cent of Canadians want a made-in-Canada solution to the financial problems facing Air Canada and Canadian Airlines.
Will the Minister of Transport commit himself and his government to finding a made-in-Canada solution? Will he further commit himself to not raising the threshold of foreign ownership in any Canadian airline or in any Canadian transportation entity? Will he make that commitment?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member will remember I have said for many months, whenever either of the two airlines make a proposal to salvage the industry and salvage the competitive nature of the aviation industry in Canada, that we would look at it.

Mr. Speaker, while I recognize that the minister has not received any formal proposals from anyone, he must be aware that there have been discussions between officials of the airlines and the Government of Canada. He must realize that Canadian is desperately seeking some solution. He also knows that the CEO of American Airlines was in Toronto this week.
Will he make a clear indication to the people of Canada that he will not deviate at any time for any
reason from the 25 per cent maximum foreign ownership prescribed in the National Transportation Act?
Maybe I have not been clear enough, Mr. Speaker. We will look at any proposal that will ensure that we maintain a viable, efficient and secure airline industry in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
Given that Canadians shop more and more across the border in the United States, does the minister intend to launch a buy Canadian campaign or to announce some other measure to counter the disastrous effects of cross-border shopping?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member raises an interesting question.
Yes, I have seen the newspaper article about it. I must point out that a study published this year showed that Canadians' major expense items-housing, transportation, education, health-cost less in Canada than in the United States if the broader picture were considered and not just the price of a quart of milk or a pound of butter.
So I think that a campaign to make Canadian consumers aware of the importance of buying at home and particularly, Mr. Speaker, of participating in the prosperity and competitiveness initiative of the industry and employment ministers will make Canadians realize that if we are more competitive, the Canadian market will be more active and consumers will gain thereby, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources.
Is the minister aware that Gulf Canada, which just pulled out of its $1 billion commitment to Hibernia, has now made a similarly large commitment to an oil project in Siberia? Will the minister confirm what Revenue



Canada told Gulf, namely that it could deduct 100 per cent of its costs in Siberia over 10 years from its taxable income in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Gulf Canada, along with Brit Gas, has a deal in Siberia. The expenditure profile, as I have been given to understand, is about $250 million Canadian of which Gulf owns half. It could result in the kinds of figures that the hon. member has mentioned. Gulf got its first oil out last week, I believe Thursday to Friday night.
That being the case, I remind the hon. member that what he said about the write-offs for Canadian companies investing in foreign oil or gas plays is correct. That dates back to 1971. In 1971 a provision was put into the Income Tax Act whereby there is a write-off against Canadian tax. This is not unique to the oil and gas industry, but it is a provision of the Income Tax Act for Canadian companies investing and earning profit outside Canada.

Mr. Speaker, that answer should be taken with a large dose of Siberian salt. It was the Liberal government that brought in the PIPs and encouraged companies to invest in Canada. It was this government that cancelled them and beefed up the foreign provisions.
Is the minister also aware that Petro-Canada, which just announced substantial cuts in this country and was trying to sell some of its shares in the Hibernia project, has now committed itself to a major oil development in Burma, and that the Department of National Revenue has informed it that it too can deduct 100 per cent of all of its costs in Burma whether the project succeeds or not?
Will the government explain to the people of Canada why in this time of recession it is encouraging the flow of Canadian money to places like Burma and Siberia? Canadians would like to send this government to Siberia.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, some of us came from Siberia so we could help this country. Some of our family members came out of Siberia as prisoners only two years ago. I do
Oral Questions
not think I need even jocular comments about Siberia or some of the contributions that were made.
I say to the hon. member that he can go back to the PIPS agreement. If he looks at PIPS, he will find that for every $1 that was invested by Canadians and others in Canada, the Canadian taxpayer paid $1.04 to $1.05 and actually lost money.
If he wants to see the success of the program, I remind him of Dome and the costs on Dome. I remind him also about tax provisions which have come to be known in jocular verbiage as the little Egypt bump. There were all kinds of examples where the Canadian taxpayer because of that kind of program lost great amounts of money. It did not help us either in reserves or in building a Canadian industry.
The fact of the matter is he can say what he will, but I go back to this simple point: this provision dates back to 1971 when I think it was his party that was in power.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Indian and Northern Affairs.
There is a serious problem at the Tobique Indian Reserve, New Brunswick, where sewage treatment facilities are apparently inadequate and raw sewage has been flowing into the Saint John River system.
I understand that the Department of Indian and Northern Affairs has been aware of this problem for many months but no corrective action has yet occurred.
What steps are being taken to stop this unacceptable environmental damage and when can effective results be expected?

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has raised a very serious problem, one which concerns me deeply.
Apparently raw sewage is being allowed to overflow from the Tobique Indian Reserve into the Saint John River, threatening the health of hundreds of thousands of residents both on reserve and in downstream communities.

February 6, 1992
Oral Questions
It is important that the House know that a capital financial agreement, a five-year financial plan signed in 1990, provided a $1.2 million allocation for the construction of a sewage treatment plant out of a total capital budget of almost $6 million. That money has not been allocated for the purpose for which it was intended. I have instructed my officials to meet with the chief and council immediately to ensure that the conditions of the funding arrangement are lived up to.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
Last night CBC's Journal aired a documentary exhibiting the historic and ongoing brutality of the Indonesian government against the East Timor people. The Indonesian government's own report of the November 12 killings is unsatisfactory and subsequent reports of retaliation against the witnesses must be investigated.
I have asked this question before. I repeat it: Will the government insist that the UN make an independent investigation of the East Timorese killings and the subsequent abuses against the East Timorese?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as you know, I have told the House before that the day after this event I raised it with the foreign minister of Indonesia with whom I was meeting in Seoul, Korea and expressed Canada's condemnation even at that early stage before we had all the facts.
In the meantime, I know that Canadians have found the information that has come forth, not just because of the video last night but as the news has come out about the incident, as reprehensible as does this government.
We cut our aid to Indonesia as a result of that. Some other countries did do it but have since reinstated it. We have not made any change in our policy toward Indonesia at this stage.
I am encouraged that the Secretary-General of the UN will be sending a special envoy to Indonesia and we will look for some results from that meeting.
[Translation}

My supplementary question is for the same minister, Mr. Speaker.
In 1975, Indonesia illegally invaded and took control of the independent country of East Timor. Since then, the Canadian government's reaction has been terribly quiet.
Will the government today join the European Community in asking the new Secretary-General of the United Nations to call a negotiating session between the parties directly concerned, such as Portugal, Indonesia and representatives of the government of East Timor?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the government supports the United Nations in the steps which still have to be made with respect to the special envoy who was sent to Indonesia by the United Nations. The Secretary-General agrees to send someone. After that, perhaps we could go on to the other steps.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to whomever is answering on behalf of the Minister of Finance.
All the government will know that when the GST was introduced the Prime Minister and the government promised that it would not be charged on the necessities of life. Now the Minister of Finance has imposed the goods and services tax on water on 26 communities across Saskatchewan, and he has done so retroactively.
I would like to ask the minister this: Will the government keep its promise and axe the tax on water?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must admit that I am not sure what the hon. member is talking about. If he had given me notice before Question Period, I would have looked into it for him and got him an answer.
February 6, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the people of Saskatchewan and Yukon know about it and they are complaining about the imposition of this tax.
We on this side of course are opposed to the GST and would scrap it. But the government has at least always admitted that it would examine the concerns about the effectiveness and the administration of the tax.
I wonder if, in response to the minister's question, he might go on to commit himself to at least looking at the implications of this tax and perhaps consider scrapping it.

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I believe the hon. member is a little confused. The short answer to his specific question is no.
The answer on the water is also no because we are not taxing water. What the hon. member is referring to is the delivery of water, and he should know that individual-
Oh, oh.
I know hon. members would want to allow the minister to give his response to the question. The hon. minister.

Mr. Speaker, if they would only listen, I am trying to explain as best I can. I would be very happy to offer them a briefing by officials to show them in detail specifically how this is being dealt with from an administrative standpoint, because those companies that deliver water can opt to operate under the same conditions as municipalities which are exempt or get a rebate on the GST.
The hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean. Just one question, please.

subtopic: REFERENDUM ON THE FUTURE OF QUEBEC
REFERENDUM ON THE FUTURE OF QUEBEC
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
Today's Le Soldi reported an incredible statement by Claude Beauchamp, president of the Regroupement Eco-
Business of the House
nomie et Constitution, who objected to a referendum on the future of Quebec, and I quote: "The risk is far too great that voters would reject an agreement. A referendum is a complex instrument. A referendum entails a risk, and the risk is that it would be defeated".
This federal spokesman from Quebec seems to be afraid Quebecers will speak out. Mr. Speaker, I want to ask the minister to dissociate himself from these undemocratic remarks and to state once and for all that the future of Quebec will not be decided on by politicians behind closed doors, but by the people of Quebec.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
subtopic: REFERENDUM ON THE FUTURE OF QUEBEC
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, perhaps the hon. member could arrange to get in touch directly with Mr. Beauchamp. I am here to answer questions about the Canadian government's policies. Or else, if he does not want to speak to Mr. Beauchamp directly, perhaps he could write a book and ask Mr. Beauchamp to read it.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the government House leader.
Would he indicate to the House the business we will be having for tomorrow, Monday, Tuesday, and the remaining parts of next week? Would he also indicate whether or not there would be some degree of co-operation on his part, as exhibited by his parliamentary secretary earlier this day, in perhaps having a special debate with regard to the whole supply management system in Canada which is presently under negotiation under the provisions of GATT?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in response to the business question, today I would hope we would complete third reading of Bill C-32 respecting the Canada Assistance Plan and, if completed, we would call for third reading Bill C-35, the Miscellaneous Statutes Act.

February 6, 1992
Business of the House
Friday we would expect to complete third reading on Bill C-35 and upon its completion the government would call Bill S-2, the Tax Convention Act, for second reading.
On Monday it would be my intention to call for second reading Bill C-26, Public Service 2000, and on Tbesday to continue second reading hopefully to completion of Bill C-26.
Next Wednesday I would intend to call an allotted day or an opposition day.
In terms of the general question, as I have said to the hon. member on many occasions, I feel that we could probably use our time in a more fitting way on many occasions around here to discuss subjects of interest and of some import if we could find some way to accommodate it within the constraints of time in terms of getting the legislation through, in terms of recognizing that we have opposition days on which the opposition can choose the subject matter and in fact from time to time schedule debates in the evening for special subjects as we have done, for example, with regard to the constitutional question tonight, next Monday, Tbesday and Thursday.
I would hope that we could get together and discuss to see whether it really is necessary to have three full days, for example, on Bill C-32 at third reading, which is a long way through the process. Perhaps we could cut that down to two days and have the third day allocated to subject matter of interest, or we could do that on similar bills.
I am always available for that kind of accommodation, but it is very difficult for me to agree to a process that says the government will continue in essence, figuratively, to get down on its knees and say: "Please allow us to pass this legislation", then in addition open up extra time for special debates of the opposition's choosing. There is just not enough time on the calendar. I would love to co-operate. I think we can co-operate. If we agree, there has to be a little give and take on both sides.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to indicate to the House that there has been a good deal of co-operation among all parties with regard to the debate which will be taking place this evening on constitutional renewal to give members an opportunity to put their concerns before the House and thereafter table documents with
the committee. I want to thank the government House leader, who has been very co-operative in that process.
I also want to say to the hon. member that my question was not intended to interfere or delay the activities of the government which has the sole right in setting the agenda in terms of legislation for this House. We are not suggesting that. In view of the comments, and he might want to take some time to discuss with his Parliamentary Secretary, under the provisions of either Standing Order 52 or some other arrangements, debates could take place later in the evening on subjects that a good majority of members of Parliament find to be important, ones which affect their constituents and are important for the country.
This is not to mean this in a partisan way. I just point out to the government House leader that, as he knows, we are in a difficult economic situation and there are issues that all Canadians would like to see us debating on the floor of this House of Commons. On the other hand, we would avail ourselves as opposition parties to select some of those subjects which can be debated under provisions of allotted days, opposition days. I suggest quite sincerely to the government House leader that there is a menu of economic issues out there which will require the special attention and co-operation of the government in order to debate it in what I believe is a very sincere way to try to find some solutions in order to put Canadians back to work.
That is the spirit in which I ask the question. Perhaps later this day or perhaps next week we might be able to pursue those discussions with the government House leader and his parliamentary secretary to arrive at some sort of accommodation for the government in its dealings here.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make a short comment regarding the points raised by my hon. friend, the opposition House leader, and ask the minister a question.
First of all, I want to say to the minister that it is appropriate that we take some days to debate important legislation. I think that Bill C-32 is one of those pieces. As a result we could move expeditiously on other pieces of legislation like C-35 and S-2.1 think we can come to an accommodation without any difficulty.
February 6, 1992

I simply want to indicate again my enthusiasm and my willingness to move expeditiously through the usual channels to see if we can facilitate arriving at ways and means of allowing additional debates on important and topical issues.
I have two questions. One concerns the budget. February is the normal time when we look forward to a budget. I wonder if the minister can give us some indication of what would be an appropriate time, or his best guess at this time, for a budget to be presented in the House. Since we are indicating the business coming up, I believe the government House leader indicated that next Wednesday would be an allotted day. Perhaps to provide for ease of preparations and planning, since it is an opposition day and will be a New Democrat sponsored motion, we will be indicating that we will be putting forward a motion on the protection of marketing boards and the opposition to tariffication to debate and we are likely to vote next Wednesday.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
In terms of the budget, as the hon. member knows, in 1984 when this government was elected we did establish the practice of bringing down the budget at the same time as the spending estimates.
To us it makes sense that they come down together and not be separated by many months, as used to be the case. The taxes and the spending ought to be related. It is our hope to keep that pattern. The specific date I cannot give the hon. member at this point.
I welcome the news that the hon. member has indicated that his party would like to discuss this important subject of GATT and marketing boards next Wednesday. By putting it to a vote, I have to remind the House that as an allotted day, the motion is a motion of confidence. That forces the government to vote in opposition to the motion, whatever it might say, because allotted days were designed as a substitute for challenging the estimates.
Every motion and every vote is a confidence vote, so in advance I have to say that we will probably support the tenor of the motion because we are very much supportive of marketing boards. Very clearly, our position at GATT is completely consistent with the position that the
Business of the House
producers have suggested we take. There is no space between us and the producers on this matter.
If a motion is put forward to that effect on an allotted day, we may have to vote against because it is a confidence motion. That is one of the other nuances of our rules that perhaps we should be looking at, but that is the effect of calling for a vote.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has identified a problem that we are confronted with from time to time.
As he knows and I think much to our pleasure, the House is master of its own destiny. With unanimous consent we can agree to virtually anything we want in terms of proceeding with business.
It would be my intent at the appropriate time next week, after consultations with members, to put the question that we seek unanimous consent so that we will not consider the vote next Wednesday to be a vote of confidence.
I think that would be a way, if I can help the hon. minister, to get around this dilemma.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Without carrying on this debate on the floor of the House of Commons, that does not help the government as the hon. member knows.

My question is also to the government House leader.
As the minister is well aware, I wrote to him and raised in the House the issue of the royal commission on election expenses and election financing. Presumably it will be reporting to the government very soon and presumably to the public at an early date.
I wonder if the government has made any arrangements for the House of Commons to deal with and study the proposed legislation that will be part of that royal commission's report.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I have not yet. I have had some preliminary discussions with House leaders opposite and will be making a firm proposal in that regard shortly, perhaps even tomorrow.
The report of the royal commission will be distributed one day next week. The only reason for not knowing that day is in the interests of all Canadians having access to it at the same time. It needs to be transported around the country.

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
As soon as I have established when that can be done, I will announce to the House the release of the report and how it is going to be treated.

Mr. Speaker, I just wanted to take this opportunity to put a question to the government House leader on House business.
With respect to the commitment that the government made some six years ago to amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act a commitment which has been reiterated in a couple of Speeches from the Throne, I would like to ask the government House leader if he can indicate to the House when the government intends to bring forward these long overdue amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act.
These are amendments which affect the physically and mentally disabled in the area of reasonable accommodation. They are amendments which affect the lesbian and gay community in the area of sexual orientation. When will the government finally move forward on these long overdue amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: This question period usually deals with the business for next week and it will not be next week.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order to comment upon statements and remarks made earlier in this House by the member for Calgary Southwest.
Last evening, the Canadian Genetic Disease Network announced that Dr. Robert Korneluk of the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario, one of the network's 23 principal investigators, has isolated the genetic defect responsible for myotonic dystrophy.
This is one of a series of genetic discoveries in Canada. The last three have been made by members of this specific network, created in 1989, the network of Centres of Excellence.
In this case, the network provided $450,000 to that research.

I think all members would have no disagreement with what the hon. minister is saying and what the member for Calgary Southwest said earlier today and also what the member for Sault Ste. Marie said about the discovery and the scientist who made the discovery. My difficulty is procedural.
The hon. minister is getting very close to a minister's statement. If the House wishes to allow the minister to proceed, I would let him.
Mr Riis: Although it obviously is not a point of order, it is an important issue to which I think all sides would wish to make a comment. May I suggest as a way out that for tomorrow under Routine Proceedings, at the time of ministerial statements, the minister take some time and make a proper statement and that would allow others to make a response as well.

Mr. Speaker, I agree with the proposal that has just been made. Certainly our party would want to join in any such statement. We were not given any prior notice that this would be coming up at this particular time.
Mr. Speaker, I would like to add my strong voice for that approach. This is a non-partisan issue and I think all sides of the House must participate in the tribute and appreciation.
I would be happy to do that except tomorrow at this time I will be speaking to members of the research community about this particular incident.

As I indicated to the hon. minister, and he has certainly seen the response, there is a disposition in the House to extend congratulations from all members, obviously. If the minister cannot be here, he may want to make some other arrangement with another minister, but it really is a very appropriate circumstance for a minister's statement.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Mazankowski that Bill C-32, an act to amend the Canada Assistance Plan, be read the third time and passed.
February 6, 1992

At one o'clock when the House adjourned, I was pointing out that for me, particularly as a member of Parliament from British Columbia, it is a pleasure to be able to participate in this very important debate on the government's proposed cutbacks on basic and fundamental financial support to the people of British Columbia.
Late last year, the Vancouver city caucus of elected representatives met in the city of Vancouver. The Vancouver city caucus is a group of elected representatives, chaired by the mayor of Vancouver, Gordon Campbell, and is made up of members of city council, the school board, provincial elected representatives and all five of the federal members of Parliament from the city of Vancouver.
At that city caucus meeting, we heard from speaker after speaker that one of the most critical issues facing the city of Vancouver and the people of British Columbia was the cutback by this Conservative government on the commitments it had made under the Canada Assistance Plan.
We know that the British Columbia Court of Appeal ruled that this particular attempt to betray a commitment that had been made to the people of British Columbia was illegal. Unfortunately, that decision was reversed by the Supreme Court of Canada.
One of the major reasons that we in the New Democratic Party so strongly support a social charter, a charter that sets out the fundamental values that shape this country in economic, social and cultural terms, is that hopefully such a charter and the existence of such a charter would prevent this kind of betrayal from taking place.
We are seeing the people of British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario particularly the victims of Bill C-32, being punished for the bankrupt economic policies of the Conservative government.
We have seen a series of these policies, whether it be the trade deal or other. I remember very well during the election of 1988 when the Conservative Prime Minister travelled across the land saying: "There are going to be hundreds of thousands of new jobs created by the trade deal". Members of this House will remember that.
Instead of creating new jobs in this country the trade deal resulted in the destruction of hundreds of thousands of jobs right across this land. As well, we have seen the erosion in social services and the attacks under way on marketing boards in this country. As a result of the trade deal there is now the suggestion that Canada
Government Orders
should go even further, that we should enter into a trade deal with the United States and Mexico.
That would be the end of any kind of manufacturing sector in this country. The cheap labour in the Maquiladora zone in Mexico obviously would be a magnet which would result in the effective shutting down of Canadian industry.
What we see in Bill C-32 is part of a trend by this Conservative government to off-load its responsibilities as a national government on to provincial governments. We have seen the impact of that in the province of Ontario in which the New Democratic government of Ontario has very courageously said that it will not be the poorest and the most vulnerable to pay the price of this government's economic policies.
We are seeing it in British Columbia where since 1982 some $1.1 billion has been off-loaded as a result of the policies, both of the Conservative government and of the previous Liberal federal government. This amounts to some 67 per cent of the estimated 1991-92 budget deficit of $1.7 billion. It is the victims of this government's economic policies who are being asked to pay the price.
We know that as unemployment insurance benefits run out, people turn in despair to welfare. That is the only thing they have left. I have met with many of the employees of Versatile Pacific Shipyards in my constituency, men who have worked there for 25, 30 or 35 years and are proud of the work they do. Yet, as a result of this government's economic policies, Versatile Pacific has thrown these people out of work. Their unemployment insurance has expired and now they are on the welfare rolls. This government's policies mean that there are going to be less and less funds available to help those who are most desperate and who are most in need. Who are they? They are children. The people most affected by these policies, by this cap on the CAP, are children. We know that children are the greatest recipients of social assistance.

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
We know that this government's policies will mean that the Prime Minister's promises at the United Nations children's summit are very hollow when the policies that attack children result in even more poverty and result in more line-ups at food banks.
We know that shelters for battered women are funded under the Canada Assistance Plan, and funds for these shelters are being cut back. We know that the already desperate circumstances of people living with AIDS, people with HIV, are being made worse as a result of the cutbacks in the Canada Assistance Plan. Some members of this House will remember the government promising with great fanfare a national child care program. Where is it? It is nowhere to be found. Another casualty of this government's appalling economic policies.
What are the alternatives? The government is clearly saying that it does not have enough money. The fact of the matter is that if this government would bring in a fair tax system, it would have the revenues necessary to ensure that the scourge of children living in poverty is put to an end. The poverty of women, particularly single parents, could be put to an end.
The member for Mississauga asks what kind of taxes we are talking about. I will tell the member for Mississauga. In 1986 there were 89,000 corporations which paid not one penny in income tax despite the fact that they recorded collective profits of $22 billion.
I will tell the hon. member that the Canadian banks have had one of the most successful records in history in this country. Are they paying their fair share in taxes? No way.
Instead of attacking children and instead of attacking the poorest and the most vulnerable in Canada, why does this government not get tough with the banks, with the wealthy, with the corporate elite who for too long have not paid their fair share? In fact from 1986 to 1989 corporate taxes went down 20 per cent under Conservative government policies and their profits in that same period of time went up by 34 per cent. Where is the fairness in that?
This is the same government that brings in policies cutting back on the Canada Assistance Plan which is a plan that was brought into existence to ensure that the poor, the most vulnerable, those living on social assistance were entitled to live with some decency, some
dignity and some sense of economic security. This government's policies are attacking that.
We know as well that this government's policies have resulted in an erosion of the quality of health care and post-secondary education in British Columbia. The cutbacks under the EPF, the Established Programs Financing Act, under Bill C-69 and other programs have meant that the share of the federal government in post-secondary education and health care has declined dramatically. In fact the cash component under this Conservative government is going to disappear entirely within the next decade.
I see it in my own constituency. I see the effect of these cuts at the B.C. Institute of Technology, at Simon Fraser University, on students attending Douglas College and others. There are programs which are victims of this government's attacks under the EPF and the Canada Assistance Plan.
Surely it is time that Parliament said to this government that enough is enough. The gap between the rich and the poor in this country is increasing. The number of people on social assistance in British Columbia and elsewhere is going up instead of down and this government is cutting back on its fundamental obligations under the Canada Assistance Plan to ensure that those programs are properly funded.
In conclusion, I want to say again that we as New Democrats reject this bill and the approach of this government which is victimizing those who are poorest and most vulnerable. We know it is happening at the international level as well. I see it happening in the city of Vancouver and in the province of British Columbia. It is time for a new government which puts people first instead of banks and the corporate elite.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I know the Speaker wants to pursue something which arose this morning and he will be in the House momentarily. I will recognize the hon. member for Mississauga South but I will tell him that he may be interrupted momentarily.

Madam Speaker, I do not intend to speak long or completely, but I want to point out that the obligation of government is to use the resources that we collect from the people of Canada to pay the bills of Canada.
This bill rations that money.
February 6, 1992

subtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 AGRICULTURE-SPEAKER'S RULING
MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 AGRICULTURE-SPEAKER'S RULING
speechtext:
The hon. member would do a courtesy to the Chair to let me interrupt him. It does not happen often but I have to deal with another matter.
There was an application made earlier today for an emergency debate by the hon. member for Algoma. As members know, the consequence of discussions earlier this afternoon related to the usual Thursday afternoon question and an allotted day has been set for next week. The hon. member for Kamloops has indicated that the subject of the application for the emergency debate will be the subject of the allotted day debate. This was brought on immediately today by the hon. member for Algoma and had been brought on earlier in the week by others, including the hon. member for Mackenzie. As a consequence, I would of course be bound by the stricture on the Speaker that in cases where there is an application for an emergency debate and there is another available opportunity for hearing it, it would not be appropriate to go ahead with the order.
Clearly the debate on Wednesday on the subject matter of the application puts that stricture on the Speaker and I do not need to deal further with the application for the emergency debate.
Throughout this entire matter I thank all hon. members and I thank the hon. government House leader this afternoon for his disposition of the matter.
The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Mazankowski that Bill C-21, an act to amend the Canada Assistance Plan, be read the third time and passed.

Madam Speaker, when I was speaking earlier, I suggested that the job of government is to take the scarce resources that
Government Orders
government can raise in taxation and try to manage those scarce resources as best as possible.
This bill increases the transfer of money to the Canada Assistance Plan by 5 per cent over and above what it would normally be. Bear in mind that inflation is now likely to be 1 per cent or 2 per cent this year. Possibly it could be as high as 3 per cent, but in most cases it is likely to be more like 2 per cent or less. This is a very substantial and real increase in the transfer of money from a government coffer that is exceedingly poor.
Anyone who reads the material coming available will know that tax revenues in the country are off about $8 billion, yet this government is still able to make a very substantial increase in transfers to provincial governments to solve problems.
The Canada Assistance Plan is a vital and important program for Canada to try to look after those people who for want of a job, for want of opportunity, for want of education, for want of many things have difficulty in looking after all of their responsibilities themselves. That there are a lot of people in our country who need help is taken for granted.
What we have to do as government is ration our scarce reserves and this bill attempts to do that in a realistic fashion. I am indeed surprised that the opposition would filibuster this bill as it has now for three days to try to hammer home some point to throw all caution to the wind and just pay and pay and pay without paying attention to the fact that this bill makes a substantial increase over and above inflation. This is a real increase in the amount of scarce money that can be applied.
The previous speaker spoke of Versatile Pacific and how that company went broke. A lot of companies have gone broke. They have had to restructure and they cannot make it together. Corporate profits in this year are as low as they have been historically since the very worst time in the Great Depression. It is less than 5 per cent on average. The effect is that proposals to beat up business by the New Democratic Party are only proposals designed to force on more unemployment.
That is what they are doing in Ontario.

Indeed that is what they are doing in Ontario. Their whole game in Ontario was spend the system broke. We did not have $341 billion of outstanding market debt. If we were not using 35 per cent or 36 per cent of the tax revenues we receive just to pay interest, perhaps we would have more money to make

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
those transfers that are obviously needed. What we need to have is some sensibility from this House of Commons.
I think it is the responsibility of members to stand and speak not of the problems but of the solutions. The suggestion of a solution to beat up on corporate taxes by grabbing and taking and making sure that companies cannot exist and go broke is really not much of a solution. It only adds to the problem.
Adding to the debt only adds to the problem because the debt must be carried. It is about time we had some solutions other than the cry of demand and the complaint of cutback. There is no cutback here. There is a substantial increase of transfer over and above inflation at a time when government revenues are suffering and suffering greater than they have for a long period of time.
It is time we had some responsible comment from the New Democratic Party members and not crazy rhetoric. They ought to know better and if they do not know better then the people of Canada ought to listen closely to them and see what a wreck they are making of Ontario and maybe they will make the same wreck of their province of British Columbia. Who knows? I can say to you, Madam Speaker, that you cannot spend yourself rich.

Madam Speaker, this is the third time I am speaking on this bill. This is something I do not usually do. I feel if you have spoken once on the subject, you have had your say. The damages that this bill will do to our country are so great, however, I feel that I must speak even a third time. Somehow this government is not listening.
I would not mind if the government did not listen to the Official Opposition of this House. I would not mind if this government would not listen to the New Democratic Party. But I do mind, and I am angry as hell, when this government has stopped listening to Canadians. It has stopped listening to Canadians coast to coast to coast.
The government members experienced this during the winter break just as we did. I am sure they took the opportunity as I did to go and visit the businesses in then-area and talk to the people in their area. They would get the true picture of what this country has come down to
after seven years of Tory government. I used to hear. "Tbry times are tough times". I certainly believe it now.
I canvassed the businesses along some of the main streets in Toronto: King Street, Queen Street, Dufferin and Dundas. It is a little scary to see five or six stores closed. The windows are boarded up. Some are for lease and some for sale because of the damage of the recession. It is scary.
I looked up a small business that employed 50 people. It was a firm which imported fabric from Pakistan and Poland to make napkins and tablecloths. During the 1988 election that company warned me: "Mr. Flis, if the government brings in the free trade agreement, I will not survive". Out of interest I went to this firm to see how it was doing and to compliment the firm. I went there. The doors were closed. The firm did not survive the free trade agreement.
The businesses which are hanging in tell me they have lost 30 to 50 per cent of their revenues over last year.
I ask what the cause is. What is happening? Why are you losing business, why are you going under? Some who are still in business say they are just hanging in, but if this recession lasts much longer, they are going under as well.
I think the minister led Canadian businesses astray when almost a year ago he said that the recession was over. People built up their hopes. "Oh, well, if the recession is almost over I think I can hang in there. I will invest a little more, et cetera". A year later the recession is not over. The government fooled the people.
Getting back to the causes, one cause was the mismanagement of this government; the second cause was the free trade agreement; the third cause was the GST) and then just an over-all frustration. Many businesses would tell me to tell the government to stop taxing them to death. They felt it was the over-taxation that was killing their businesses.
I said to them that we have a great country here, we have built in certain social safety nets, we have an excellent medicare system, an excellent education system. Someone has to pay for that. The government has to get revenue to pay for these things. What is your solution? Again, their solution was to stop taxing them to death. They want the government to put money into people's pockets, quickly, now, not a year from now. They also said build up confidence. The people who have the money are afraid to spend it. They are afraid to spend it because they do not know whether they will have a job next week or next month. The people who

have the money are not spending it because of the lack of confidence created by this government in this country. The ones who do not have the money cannot spend something they do not have.
It was very rewarding for me to talk to people from all walks of life, going into the garages and seeing how hard the mechanic was working over his motor, going into the back of the restaurants to see how hard the people were working just to make ends meet. Some people would apologize because their hands were soiled and they did not want to shake hands with their MP. I said they never had to apologize for dirty hands. It is those kinds of hands that built this country to what it is today.
I offer the government what I heard on the streets during the winter break, and I am sure it is what the Conservative members heard also. As I said earlier, they have stopped listening.
From there my assistant and I then dropped in to one of our larger Canada employment offices right on Bloor Street. Another frightening picture was to see the Canada employment office packed with people just before Christmas. They were lining up for various things, unemployment insurance, lining up because someone lost a social insurance number and was making application, lining up because of Canada Employment and Immigration disputes or conflicts.
Again, it was revealing to talk to these people while they were standing in line. They had a certain amount of satisfaction and security because they were lining up to apply for their unemployment insurance. Many of them spoke to me with almost fear on their faces because they were afraid of what would happen to them when their UI revenues would run out: "Mr. Flis, what am I going to do when I exhaust my UI? I want to work. I have tried 200 firms. No one will take me." That is when the fear starts coming in. What will happen when that safety network of UI and then social assistance runs out? This is where panic sets in, this is where psychological depression sets in.
My constituency office, like many members' offices, has become an employment agency. People who have been working 10 years, people who have had businesses
Government Orders
and are now unemployed are coming to their member of Parliament and asking: "Mr. Flis, can you help me get something? I will take any work, but I will not go on welfare".
Many Canadians are so proud that they will not go on welfare. They want to help themselves. They want to work. Again, this government is not allowing this.
Following this kind of talking and listening to the people in Parkdale-High Park, I brought all of their concerns to the three-day caucus meeting the national Liberal caucus had in Ottawa prior to the opening of the House of Commons on February 3.
Each member shared what he or she heard from people in their ridings. Based on what we heard, the Liberal Party came up with a five-point economic recovery plan. I will not waste the time of the House to repeat it because it has been repeated over, over and over here.
We are pleased that the government already implemented one of our recommendations, the 5 per cent down payment, et cetera. We are just waiting and hoping that it will implement the other four, especially the infrastructure one. If it does not, the doom and gloom will lead to violence and civil disobedience.
I just want to share with this House that the people in Parkdale-High Park have called in the Guardian Angels, some from the United States, to come and help them supervise the streets. They feel that the streets are not safe any more.
I disagree with them. I object. I go on public record. I object to any Guardian Angels coming in and telling us how to supervise our streets. In metropolitan Toronto we have the best police force in Canada. People feel secure with its supervision, its policing. We do not need any Guardian Angels from any U.S. city.
We have nothing to learn from United States cities. Our cities are still relatively safe and pleasant places to live. I hope the government will listen to our five-point economic recovery plan.

Madam Speaker, I want to just put a few words on the record as they relate to this bill.

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
The general thrust of the Government of Canada is to cut existing programs, programs that affect our education, our health and our social security. I would like to put on the record that the Government of Canada has a double standard here.
Over the past year, the Government of Canada has given up more income than I have seen since I became a member of Parliament several years ago.
Let me put on the record two incredible changes that took place in the Income Tax Act. In the past year, the law was changed in relation to deferred taxes that were supposed to be paid to the Government of Canada.
What are deferred taxes?

The hon. member wants to know what a deferred tax is.
I am going to explain to the hon. member exactly what happened and he will remember exactly what I am talking about.
Back in 1972 the Liberal government changed the law in relation to moneys that were collected through what was then called the estate tax, which imposed a sliding tax on wealthy, rich inheritances. That was replaced by a capital gains tax.
You stopped the loophole.

If the hon. member listens he might learn something. The capital gains tax was brought in to replace the estate tax. It was 50 per cent of the rate charged on normal income. There was a provision in the law at that time to protect the Government of Canada against the moneys that would have normally been paid on capital gains but not moneys that were held in private trusts. The rule was called the 21-year rule. Now the hon. member knows what I am talking about. Now he knows what I am going to say.
The 21-year rule was that although a trust never dies, although a trust goes on indefinitely, regarding the capital gains that were held in those trusts, the taxes that would have normally been paid, that were paid by every small businessman in this country, that were paid by every construction man in this country, by everybody who built houses, who contributed something to the economy, they all had to pay up on their capital gains tax. They
all paid up because the law is the way it is in Canada and nobody is disputing it. There was a provision that there would be a 21-year period and then those capital gains that had piled up, those taxes that would have normally been paid, were in a private trust and they could not be collected, but at the end of 21 years they would come due to the Government of Canada.
We can imagine how much money is in private trusts in Canada.
Very little.

The hon. member says very little in private trusts. He should read the Department of Finance's breakdown for 1986. The end of the 21 years is the end of this year and all of those taxes that were normally paid on capital gains would have accumulated and would be payable on the 21st year. Do you know what the Government of Canada did in this Chamber? The hon. member does not like hearing it.
It stopped the alternation of the trust.

It altered the rule. It threw out the 21-year rule. It threw it out. What did it replace it with? It said: "Those taxes can be further delayed and they become payable with the death of the youngest member of that family". By any estimate, the hon. member would ask how many years that would put off the taxes-30 years, 40 years, 60 years; massive sums of money due the Government of Canada from people who have so much money that they just do not have to move it, they can tuck it away in private trusts.
The Government of Canada changed the law and said: "You do not have to pay that now". Out goes the 21-year rule because it is up at the end of this year 1972 and 21 makes 1993.
My time is short but I will make reference to one other thing that really bothers me. It concerns the change to section 67.5 of the Income Tkx Act that deals with what qualifies for a deduction in entertainment. Do you know what the Government of Canada did? Did anybody ever look at why we have such a substantial increase in the amounts of money claimed under entertainment deductions on income tax returns?
Normally it goes this way. If you entertain a person for business purposes and you are trying to sell a product or
February 6, 1992

you are trying to sell your business, certain costs are legitimate. For example, people can write off the cost of their expensive meals. They can write off the cost of their big booze parties if they wish. They could have written off the cost of their yachts up to 1987. They can write off many things that in the normal running of a business is recognized by the business community as being a legitimate expense.
Consider what the Government of Canada did last month in December. There were tax lawyers and accountants asking National Revenue: "Does this qualify? Does that qualify? How far can I go here? Can I buy a helicopter?" What did the government do in answer to all the accountants and tax lawyers in Canada who had a legitimate concern? The tax lawyers and the accountants needed to know. They needed to have some direction. The general rule was if it was not listed as an exemption in the Income Tax Act then you could claim it. They kept saying: "How far can we go?" The Government of Canada determined it in December of this year. It brought in a change to the act and said that you can go as far as the Criminal Code of Canada.
Shame.
It said it was closing a loophole. So you ask a question.
In practice.

In practice does an escort service count as a legitimate deduction? What is the reason for this substantial increase in the entertainment deductions?
The Government of Canada says that you can go as far as the Criminal Code of Canada in taking money from the public purse. It has our poor taxpayers pay the bill and says to them: "You pay the GST so that we can pass along this money to certain people who spend money on booze and escort services".
The Government of Canada should be thoroughly ashamed of itself and explain to the Canadian people why it did it.

Madam Speaker, it is always difficult to follow the hon. member for Gander-Grand Falls. His eloquence never
Government Orders
fails to amaze me. It must be something in the maritime blood indeed.
I would like to add a few of my comments with regard to Bill C-32.1 do honestly believe that this is a bad piece of legislation. This is an immoral piece of legislation. This is legislation that should never be.
Bill C-32 allows for the extension of the five per cent limit on the funds available through the Canada Assistance Plan for the provinces of Alberta, Ontario and British Columbia, which is my home province. Everyone will remember of course that some time ago Bill C-69 capped at 5 per cent the increases for federal funding assistance until 1992. The bill we have before us, Bill C-32, extends that cap up to the year 1995.
The Canada Assistance Plan is really the only mechanism or means through which the federal government funds social assistance and social services to the provinces. By extending the cap or the limit on the increases to the three provinces I have named, B.C., Alberta and Ontario, this government has been making the economic downturn significantly worse in those provinces. This is particularly so for the unemployed and those Canadians who are off unemployment insurance and require the assistance that is available through the Canada Assistance Plan.
This is the wrong way to go. We are hurting our lowest income people, those who can least afford it and are least able to defend themselves. It is simply unjust in a society such as ours that we take this kind of direction that is evidenced in this government's fiscal policies particularly with respect to this bill before us.
I want to say that every single witness who came before the finance committee on this legislation urged the government to withdraw this bill because of its harmful impact.
In British Columbia, despite the fact that we have just had a recent election of a new government, social assistance recipients cannot afford to eat a decent meal. I know it is doing all it can to reverse this trend. Welfare payments to a family of four in British Columbia fell short some $18.30 a month for food alone. That means no money for toiletries, for transportation, for clothing

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
or for recreation,. There is not even the basic allowance to put food on the table. This bill has made things that much worse for those people.
Families and children rely on the Canada Assistance Plan which this bill wants to handicap. To those people the Canada Assistance Plan is a virtual lifeline. It is largely through no fault of their own, but as some people are simply being victimized by the economic consequences in this country, their means of livelihood has become welfare.
What this government has done is it has introduced measures in the name of fiscal restraint that says the rich provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario can afford to pay the extra money that should be going to the Canada Assistance Plan. They can afford to make up the shortfall. The federal government will withdraw the extra funding. Freeze it. Put a cap on it and the provinces can make up the shortfall.
This bill is symbolic of the philosophical direction that this government has taken. It is wanting to devolve these kinds of services such as the Established Programs Financing for post-secondary education and health care and the Canada Assistance Plan. Those are the kinds of important funding mechanisms that allow the provinces to provide the quality social programs that they have been providing. The government is withdrawing from its funding support of those mechanisms. That is simply wrong. Canadians do not agree with that kind of direction that the government is taking.
I want to say that as a result of this cap on the Canada Assistance Plan, Ontario alone this year fell $900 million short. It was $900 million short.
Is that not next year?

My colleague says that it is next year. I believe that the figures are estimated over the fiscal year. We may be talking fiscal and calendar years.
Nine hundred million dollars is an incredible amount of money when you think about it. One of the reasons that the government in Ontario has had such a tough time in dealing with its rising deficit is because this federal government has pulled the plug on poor people and unemployed people in the province of Ontario. It has pulled the plug and the Ontario government has had to try to make up that shortfall.
I want to turn to a report that comes from the Government of British Columbia on the cost of the federal off-loading to British Columbia as a result of the cap on the Canada Assistance Plan.
These off-loading measures have really gone back over quite a few years as a result of the combined policies of the previous Liberal administration and now this administration. The combined effect will be some $1.1 billion in extra provincial payments that the province of British Columbia has to make good on by
1991-92.
This is an equivalent of some 67 per cent of the budget deficit that British Columbia is experiencing in the current fiscal year. This is 67 per cent of the deficit of $1.7 billion. It is just as a result of the fact that this government is not maintaining and honouring its legislative commitment to the people of British Columbia.
I want to add also that if these current off-loading measures that are going on through this kind of legislation continue in the first year of the next century by the year 2000, the fiscal impact on the province of British Columbia will be some $32.7 billion.
The B.C. report also notes that the Canada Assistance Plan is there to assist not governments but people. By withdrawing its fiscal support, this government is neglecting the people of British Columbia not the Government of British Columbia. It is trying to do the best it can to make up for the shortfall that has been caused by this government's insensitivity.
In 1991-92, $166 million will be lost to British Columbia due to the 5 per cent growth ceiling of the past legislation. As a result of this legislation which extends that freeze, it is going to make a shortfall in the Canada Assistance Plan alone by some $1 billion in 1994-95.
I know my time is limited, but I want to say on behalf of the citizens in my province of British Columbia and the citizens of my constituency of Okanagan-Shuswap that the government through this legislation is abandoning the less fortunate individuals not only in British Columbia but also throughout Canada.
The legislation is wrong. It is immoral and it should be withdrawn.

February 6, 1992

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: It is my duty, pursuant to Standing Order 38, to inform the House that the questions to be raised tonight at the time of adjournment are as follows: the hon. member for Bonavista-Ttin-ity-Conception-Fisheries; the hon. member for Nanaimo-Cowichan-Fisheries; the hon. member for Nepean-Indonesia; the hon. member for Cape Breton-Highlands-Canso-Rail Passenger Service; and the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell- Canada Post.

Madam Speaker, I also wish to participate in Bill C-32, an act to amend the Canada Assistance Plan, third reading.
I would like to outline some of the concerns that I see within my own riding. This is the second time I have risen and spoken on this situation that the government is creating. I want to also make a few comments with regard to what the member for Mississauga South had to say because he does chair the finance committee and I know the background he has. It appears that he seems very biased in his comments toward the corporations and has very little concern for the well-being of the unfortunates and the people who need the help the most.
During the 1988 election campaign, the free trade agreement was the big thing that the government was talking about. There is no doubt in my mind, and all of the people I have talked to throughout not only my riding but across the country, that the actions this government is taking with regard to Bill C-32 and the capping of our social programs is an attack on the universality of our social programs.
The Prime Minister during the last election stated that our social programs were a sacred trust that would be protected by his government and the free trade agreement would not affect them. The actions this government is taking have everything to do with the free trade agreement. The cutbacks we have seen in the unemployment insurance and the changes to the unemployment insurance, the changes with regard to the various equalization payments, post-secondary education and those kinds of things are seen as subsidies. This government is
Government Orders
starting to set the wheels in motion to affect those very programs. To be capping the Canada Assistance Plan during these economic times-at Christmas I went out and visited the food banks throughout my riding and saw the line-ups-you should be ashamed of yourselves. Every one of your members should be standing up here and saying: "My goodness, we have serious economic times and this is not a time to attack the people who need the help the most".
I want to refer to some things that are going to be happening. I want to alert the people before the government brings in the budget. I saw an article on February 5: "The Canadian Manufacturers' Association makes a push for $2 billion in tax breaks". It is lobbying the federal government. It goes on: "Up to $2 billion a year in tax breaks to business should be contained in the upcoming federal budget, the Canadian Manufacturers' Association said yesterday".
The Canadian Manufacturers' Association's pre-budget submission also called on the Minister of Finance to chop social spending because of Ottawa's hefty debt.
My goodness, we have seen the amount of unemployed. We have seen the food banks and the problems they are having trying to serve these people. Here we have the Manufacturers' Association coming to the federal government and requesting $2 billion extra, but cut social programs. It will be interesting to the Canadian people to see what this government does with that request because we do know it is closely associated with this government and this government lends a very close ear to its proposals.
At the same time, in the same paper I read: "Too poor, lowest income disabled missed the tax breaks". While these kinds of tax breaks are being made available to large corporations which the member for Mississauga South seems to defend and help as a way of dealing with it, more than one-quarter of severely disabled Canadians earn so little that they get nothing from the federal disability tax credit. The finance department admits in a report contained under the Access to Information: "We estimate that 26.5 per cent of the severely disabled population are unable to claim any amount of tax credits because they have no federal tax payable".
Is it any wonder that the Canadian people are starting to question the actions of this government?

February 6, 1992
Government Orders
We see the unemployed lining up and trying to obtain their unemployment insurance benefits and finding out under the new legislation that they have been cut back on their eligibility. We see the social assistance programs being cut back, the funding to the post-secondary education programs being cut back with no way to try to support those kinds of things. This government sits here and says nothing, and does nothing to try to alleviate those kinds of things.
The major platform of Ed Broadbent, our leader in the 1980s, during the 1980 election, the 1984 election, and the 1988 election, in which I was also involved, was federal, provincial, municipal programs to spur our economy. The Liberals had a one-day meeting here in Ottawa three or four days ago and came up with the idea that it is their idea.
I want to say that it is an excellent idea because what we have here is a proposal that we can work with the municipalities as federal, provincial and municipal governments to invest in our municipalities during times of depression, to upgrade our sewer systems and our various systems to bring them on stream. It is an investment. It is not a debt. That is an investment that we are going to have to carry out to meet the environmental problems that we have across Canada. It would meet the needs of many of these people under the Canada Assistance Plan. They are there in those communities throughout Canada and they could be employed in a meaningful way which everyone of them I am sure wants to be.
This government came in and said it is not going to address those problems, it is going to cap it so less is available. It will ensure that the programs brought in are more concerned with what happens to the interest rate and what happens to the Canadian dollar. It is more concerned with that than with the people it represents.
That is not good enough and the Canadian people are not going to accept that. Enough misery has been added to the Canadian people with the goods and services tax, with the various programs that have been cut back. They have had enough and it is time that this government changed its direction and not wait until just before the election and then come out with a bunch of goodies to try to change the devastation it has caused across this country.
I heard the member from GANDER-GRAND FALLS state in his question this afternoon that this government should go to Siberia. I think that many people here would agree. In my view maybe we should not put that kind of stress on that country which has enough problems already.
Let us make sure that we get the government out of here because it has done enough damage.

Madam Speaker, in rising to speak to Bill C-32, an act to amend the Canada Assistance Plan, before I get into the substance of my remarks I want to comment briefly on the earlier interjection during the debate by the hon. member for Mississauga South.
He had the temerity to suggest that Bill C-32 was a piece of legislation which would increase the government's contribution by 5 per cent. He knows better.
The government is putting a limit on an agreed upon increase at a time when as a result of the government's policies, of which he is a member and a supporter, those welfare lines and social assistance lines are climbing out of proportion to the norm.
The member for Mississauga South and his Conservative colleagues are saying to the increasing numbers of people who are being forced to line up in soup lines, in food bank lines and in social assistance lines, after the first five people: "Sony, the rest of you 95 are out of here, even though we are responsible in large part for putting you in this line-up."
How that member can suggest that is offering something by this legislation I will never know. The hon. gentleman can be pretty clever at times, but he is a little off base this time around.
Bill C-32 allows for the extension of the 5 per cent limit on the Canada Assistance Plan for the provinces of Alberta, B.C. and Ontario. Bill C-69 capped at 5 per cent the federal funding increases until 1992 and Bill C-32 extends the cap up to 1995. The Canada Assistance Plan is the only mechanism by which the federal government funds social assistance and social services.
Like one of my colleagues previously, I want to comment just briefly on how this and similar measures by
February 6, 1992

this Conservative government have cost many of the citizens of my home province of British Columbia very dearly.
Recently, on February 4, the Government of British Columbia released a brief produced by the B.C. Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations concerning the financial toll of federal cuts to transfer payments, the Established Programs Financing for health and post-secondary education and the Canada Assistance Plan and other programs. The paper details the actions of past Liberal and Conservative federal governments and the impact they have had on the B.C. budget.
The combined effect on B.C. of off-loading measures implemented since 1982 will be $1.1 billion in 1991-92, which is equivalent to 67 per cent of the estimated
1991-92 budget deficit of $1.7 billion. If the current off-loading continues to the first year of the new century, the negative fiscal impact on B.C. will be $32.7 billion.
Regarding the Established Programs Financing, the action taken earlier, the impact of Liberal and Tory changes over the years to the EPF funding formula, will result in B.C. losing $6.8 billion by the end of 1994-95.
Regarding the Canada Assistance Plan, the B.C. report notes that Canada Assistance Plan benefits are used to assist people, not governments. In 1991-92, $166 million will be lost to B.C. due to the 5 per cent gross ceiling and more than $1 billion will be lost by 1994-95.
With those kinds of figures, it is no wonder many people in western Canada, particularly in the province of British Columbia, are wondering just what is in it for them. It does not lead to the kind of understanding that there ought to be when we are attempting to form a new Constitution and a new relationship between the various parts of Canada.
The government has introduced these measures in the name of fiscal restraint and says that it is only the rich provinces that are affected and can afford the cap. The fact is that 50 per cent of Canada's poor live in British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario. The people in these provinces are as poor as those anywhere else in Canada. If you are poor, you are poor.
The very provinces that are affected by the cap on the Canada Assistance Plan are attractive provinces for
Government Orders
those looking for work to move to, but when work is not available many of them must go on social assistance, placing an even larger burden on the welfare rolls in those provinces proportionately to those going on the welfare rolls in others.
A June 1991 Statistics Canada study shows that the large increase in the federal debt over the past 15 years was not caused by increases in program spending, as the Conservatives have alleged. That study examining the growth of the federal debt from $56 billion in 1974-75 to over $400 billion at the end of 1989-90 concludes: "It was not explosive growth and program spending that caused the increase in deficits after 1975, but a drop in federal revenues relative to the growth of the GDP and rising debt charges".
To go on: "Broadly speaking, government program spending as a share of gross domestic product did not rise significantly from 1975-in fact, it moderated compared to the preceding 10 years. Excluding unemployment insurance, which is intended to be self-financing over the business cycle, social program spending has not increased relative to GDP over the last 16 years".
In spite of the claims made by Conservatives and members on that side of the House, who tend to give weight to the mythology that it is program spending, especially social program spending, that has been largely to blame for the federal debt and use the backlash created by those kinds of statements to support their current cuts in social programs, particularly programs like the Canada Assistance Plan, facts from Statistics Canada show demonstrably that it is simply not true.
This is just one example of the social and fiscal irresponsibility on the part of successive federal governments, both Liberal and Conservative. Bill C-32 is just another example of how this government has decided to place the burden of paying off the debt on the shoulders of those who can least afford it.
Just like the NDP is doing in Ontario.

Madam Speaker, some member keeps referring to Ontario. There is a big "O", a big zero, at the beginning of Ontario and I would suggest that is where that member is. If you had taken the zeros who managed to create a terrible debt burden at a time when the economy was still growing out of Ontario,

Government Orders
nobody would have the kind of problems in Canada that we currently have.
Another problem this government is now attempting to deal with, in a rather mischievous way, stems from the ever growing debt burden that has been created since the end of the Second World War, and it was not a result of program spending. As I said before, it had much more to do with the perversions in the tax structure the Conservative Party and the Liberal Party were responsible for over many years.
For example, in 1950 direct tax revenue from both the personal and corporate sectors was approximately equal, and together they covered some three-quarters of current federal expenditures. By 1988 personal taxes had risen from 35 per cent to 47 per cent of government expenditures and corporate taxes had declined from the 1951 high of 40 per cent to only 9 per cent of government expenditures, as shown on the accompanying chart. I will supply that to Hansard. In other words, the corporate sector has managed to curtail its relative tax liability by almost 75 per cent since 1950. In 1988 terms, if the corporate sector tax contribution had matched that of personal taxpayers instead of a budget deficit of $30 billion, Ottawa would have realized a surplus of some $18.5 billion. In other words, the government could have targeted the cause but it did not. Now the poorest Canadians are paying the price.
In conclusion, I would like to point out that Bill C-32 is just another attack by the Tbries on social programs which the government claims it is making in the name of fiscal restraint. It is clear that this move is about politics, not money. These political moves amount to more breaks for the Tbries' wealthy friends and a consequent life of poverty and hunger for millions of Canadians who are being squeezed and broken by the weight of high taxes with a tattered social safety net beneath them.
In my own riding of Kootenay West-Revelstoke people are suffering. This government is making it worse. It is time it had a second thought, retreated, withdrew this bill and turned its policies around to give some hope to the people of Canada.
