subtopic: MISCELLANEOUS STATUTE LAW AMENDMENT ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I will only be speaking for a short time on this bill because, as our House leader said in previous debate,
February 6, 1992

this bill is basically a technical bill in which we are cleaning up loose ends on several other bills that have been through committee and through the House. These basically are just minor modifications.
I wanted to speak to this bill from the point of view of someone who is not a lawyer. Sometimes when I listen to debates in this House I think most Canadians get a feeling that they do not understand what it has to do with the problems and priorities of the marketplace.
As we said earlier this week on our first day back, the number one issue, the number one concern in this country today is trying to get people back to work. Then we see a bill like this on our legislative agenda in which we are addressing over 60 to 70 different statutes. He said: Madam Speaker, I commend to your attention and the attention of the House the following words and ask that you think carefully on them as I recite them:
February 6, 1992

The petition of the undersigned residents of Canada who now avail themselves of their ancient and undoubted right thus to present a grievance common to your petitioners in the certain assurance that your honourable House will therefor provide a remedy humbly sheweth-
How grand those words sound, how noble, how redolent of the comfortingly musty air of parliamentary history, tradition and practice. And yet, how hollow, how thin, how utterly void of force and meaning.
Can any member in this Chamber number the times she or he has heard these words or their latter day variants uttered during the Routine Proceedings of this House? Yet can any member name a single instance in which a petition solemnly presented here has resulted in a change of policy, a shift in spending, the taking of some requested action or the abandonment of some other? Can any member name a single instance in which beyond its perfunctory hearing, a petition's prayer was even considered in this House?
I suspect not, which is sad, and I believe dangerous.
We live in a time when many Canadians, despairing of the fruits of their parliamentary institutions and even of the general conduct of public affairs, are coming to despair of public democratic government itself, believing contemporary policies to be the creation not of the parties and politicians who transitorily inhabit and control our democratic institutions, but rather of our democratic institutions themselves. Many Canadians see institutional reform as their best chance for relief from the government policies that cause them so much pain and frustration.
So it is that we see deeply angered westerners, hit hard by depressed international commodity prices, repeating the dull incantation that a Triple-E Senate might forever save the west from another NEP or the unfair awarding of an aircraft service contract.
So it is we see deeply angered Ontarians who have watched their once mighty manufacturing sector devastated in the wake of free trade after decades of truncated branch plant development turn their fury on

constitutional guarantees of minority language rights.
So it is that we see maritimers suffering the agonies of depleted fish stocks and the shock of a GST on top of already high provincial taxes ponder the relative merits of maritime union or, like westerners, a Triple-E Senate.
And so it is we see Quebecois battling high interest rates, the high dollar and looming behind all else the dark spectre of ultimate cultural assimilation and extinction. We see them reaching for the intoxicating elixir of independence.
Everywhere, Canadians seem to be seeking institutional solutions to political problems. We should not be surprised at this. Canadians are faced with a government they seem unable to influence. They find themselves truly suffering with the consequences of policies they despise, but apparently having no means of reversing or even moderating those policies.
Canadians write letters in numbers sufficient to denude forests and are ignored. They sign protest petitions by the hundreds of thousands and are told the policies they protest are for their own good. They demonstrate on the streets of the nation in the tens of thousands and are dismissed as isolated and ignorant cranks.
In short, Canadians find themselves devoid of political influence at the very centre of those institutions which exist ostensibly to effect their will. I believe this is the fault of those currently occupying those centres. I believe the government is so blinded by its own misguided ideological mission that it refuses to see the suffering it is causing the Canadian people; refuses to see the flag of rage raised against it. I also believe that the task of those who wish to return the voice of the Canadian people to the councils of policy in power is a political task and not an institutional one.
The best and most effective response to the follies and predations of the current government would be not to change Parliament, but to change the government. I am certain this will happen at the first opportunity. I fervently hope the change will be enough to begin a reversal of the policies that have been devastating this country and not just to change the faces of those politicians uttering vacuous justifications of those policies.
Even when we do finally elect a government that will serve Canadians, it would be prudent as well to implement means to ensure that government continues serv-

Private Members' Business
mg Canadians. We must find ways of ushering the clear political voice of the Canadian people directly into our deliberations. If we are to battle the corrosive cynicism and misguided, institutionally oriented politics that now eat at the heart of true political debate in this country, we must devise means of making that debate more immediately felt in this House. We must open the doors of this Chamber to the concerted intervention of the Canadian people.
Motion No. 89 before us today is a modest attempt to begin this process. It is offered in an effort to restore some degree of credibility to our parliamentary institutions by making more real and effective the political concerns of Canadians within this institution.
This would happen by making petitions effective again. I say again because petitions have not always been the pathetic little squeaks of formulaic protest to which they are now reduced. Before the Magna Carta there were petitions directed to the Crown and, as often as not, seeking redress for some grievance, although no record exists for how often such redress was granted. The institution of petitions remains sufficiently valuable and vibrant to warrant its specific reaffirmation in the Bill of Rights of 1689. The right to petition Parliament slowly evolved out of this statutory and conventionally constitutional right to petition the Crown.
Similarly, as is noted in citation 666 at page 209 of the fifth edition of Beauchesne's:
The right of petitioning the Crown and Parliament for redress of
grievances is acknowledged as a fundamental principle of the
Constitution and has been exercised without interruption since
1867.
Exercised without interruption perhaps, but I suspect it has as well been exercised with ever lessening effect.
This was probably inevitable, but even if inevitable, the erosion of the power of petitions should now be reversed. Democratic practice requires no less.
It lies within the power of this House, through Motion No. 89, to change this, to restore to petitions the status of effective agent of the vox populi at the very heart of the parliamentary process.
The mechanism is simple. All that is required is an amendment to our Standing Orders to compel the House to debate and pass upon any matter brought to its attention by a sufficiently large number of petitioners.
Where a petition asked for something that did not require the expenditure of public money, such as a government commitment to reducing carbon dioxide emissions to 80 per cent of their 1988 level by the year 2005, the signatures of 3 per cent of the electorate, about
530,000	electors, would be enough to compel parliamentary consideration.
Where a petition asked for something that did require the expenditure of public money, such as the implementation of a new national child care program, the signatures of 5 per cent of the electorate, about 880,000 electors, would be enough to compel such consideration.
In either case, the petitions would be referred to the Chief Electoral Officer for verification of the numbers of signatures. Once certified by the Chief Electoral Officer, a petition's prayer would have to be debated in this House for a minimum of three hours on government business time. At the conclusion of that debate, the House would have to vote on whether it supported the prayer.
Contrast this proposal with the current state of affairs. Today, petitions are presented by hon. members pursuant to Standing Order 36. They then quickly subside beneath the murky parliamentary waters.
According to the fifth edition of Beauchesne's in citation 695 at page 213, unanimous consent must be granted just to have the Clerk read out a petition's prayer. The only way a petition can be referred to a committee thereafter is with another show of unanimous consent.
However, if Motion No. 89 were adopted and the House voted to support a petition's prayer, the Standing Committee on Privileges and Elections would be charged automatically with preparing a motion or a bill for an act which, if adopted by the House and the Senate in the case of a bill, would give effect to the prayer. That motion or bill would then proceed through the House as a regular piece of government business, except that if the House dissolved or prorogued the motion or bill would automatically be reinstated at the next sitting of the House at the stage and form in which it had been left at dissolution or prorogation.

36.6	which provides that no vote taken in this House on a petition's prayer or subsequent motion or bill:
-shall be deemed to involve a question of the confidence of the House in the ministry or a minister.
In other words, all votes in the House on matters arising out of petitions should be free votes.
I would like to note here that I cannot claim exclusive credit or blame, depending on your point of view, for drafting and promoting this motion and the ideas behind it. Jim Gurnett, then the member of the Alberta Legislative Assembly for the constituency of Spirit River-Fair-view, and I first cobbled together a motion very much like this one in 1985. Our goal then was the same as I have presented today: To grant people the ability directly to affect the legislative agenda of their parliaments and thereby restore at least some of the people's faith in their democratic institutions.
This proposal was the cornerstone of the Alberta New Democrats' very first public announcement in the Alberta general election of 1986. That was the election which saw their caucus grow from two to 16 members.
Unfortunately, Jim Gurnett was defeated in that election. Upon the convening of the new legislature, this motion was taken up by Gordon Wright, then the newly-elected member for Edmonton Strathcona. Both these men are among the finest I have ever had the pleasure to meet and work with and I am deeply honoured today to be advancing in this House a democratic proposal of the sort previously championed by them in the Alberta legislature.
Surely, some may say, there are other better ways to raise the voice of the Canadian people directly in their Parliament. It is true that other proposals have been made. Hon. members will know that there have been at least two proposals on the Order Paper in addition to Motion No. 89, both aimed at increasing Canadians' control over, and impact on, the political process. The hon. member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore has proposed Bill C-201, a bill for an act which would provide for the holding of referenda on various matters. The hon. member for Calgary Northeast had previously proposed Motion No. 664, a motion seeking a constitutional amendment to provide for holding of referenda when called for by a petition of 10 per cent of electors.
Both these proposals have some merit and are certainly worthy of the House's consideration. Neither can be
Private Members' Business
affected by this House acting alone. In both cases this House's hands can be tied by the Senate.
Motion No. 89 on the other hand can be adopted by the House acting on its own without reference to any other body or authority, and because it is a motion and not a bill, only one vote is required. All that is needed is a willingness on the part of no more than 148 hon. members, a simple majority, to give the people of Canada a little more say over what goes on in their Parliament.
Some may object that Motion No. 89 would have the effect of preventing those elected to govern from doing so, that it would remove decision making from the thoughtful chambers of Parliament and hurl it into the chaos and passion of street level politics. They may see in Motion No. 89 a system discomfortingly close to the form of legislation by initiative found in several American states.
Setting aside for the moment my personal conviction that this may not be such a bad thing, I must with some mixed feelings assure hon. members that this objection is groundless. All the motion provides is that the people of Canada, in sufficient numbers, may compel their Parliament to consider a matter. It remains for Parliament to decide the matter; both at the initial debate on the petition's prayer and, should the prayer be supported, at the debate on the consequent motion or bill.
Further, in precluding the operation of the confidence convention, the motion attempts to ensure that each matter brought forward by petition is considered on its merits alone.
Some may object that passage of this motion would result in legislative gridlock, that the House would be inundated with petitions seeking all manner of fanciful programs and policies and that consequently the legitimate business of the House of Commons would be shoved aside.
To this objection there are two responses. First, the number of signatures required would ensure only the most widely supported initiatives would be brought before this House in this fashion. As one who has spent more than a few hours on cold winter streets attempting to coax signatures from reluctant citizens, I can say that collecting one signature each from a minimum half

Private Members' Business
million voters is no mean feat. It requires extensive organization and widespread grassroots support for the proposition being advanced. The workout alone would be sufficient to weed out all the frivolous and most of the vexatious efforts, ensuring that only matters of substantial public interest were brought forward.
Second, there is what Beachesne's calls an old rule of Parliament. It is a rule first passed in 1604 and conventionally enforced in this House to this day. It precludes consideration of any question previously considered and passed upon in the same session. Citing the fourth edition of Bourinot, Beauchesne's at page 172 of the sixth edition, quotes this old rule as:
That a question being once made and carried in the affirmative or
negative, cannot be questioned again but must stand as the judgment
of the House.
This would ensure that only matters not previously debated and resolved by the House would be brought forward. Therefore, given these two conditions the House can be certain that only matters of great public significance not previously determined by the House would be brought forward should Motion No. 89 be adopted.
I would note parenthetically my personal hope that the rule against consideration by the House of any question more than once in a session would not be enforced so rigidly as to prevent legitimate consideration of legitimate matters legitimately placed before this House by petition. There is a danger that over-strict interpretation of this rule could itself constrict the reasonable democratic rights this Motion seeks to establish.
As well, it is greatly to be hoped that governments would not resort to the transparent strategy of quickly introducing and disposing of motions or bills which in content and purpose closely mimicked those of an anticipated petition solely for the purpose of precluding that petition's consideration.
I suggest, however, that these concerns are modest compared to the benefits to be derived from the adoption of Motion No. 89.
As I noted at the outset, it ought to be crystal clear to all hon. members that most Canadians no longer believe what they think and want matters in their Parliament. It
is equally clear that they believe there is nothing they can do about it between elections.
This condition is dangerous because it creates the sullen cynicism that can corrode public confidence in, and thus support for, the democratic institutions that constitute the bedrock upon which our civil society is built.
I believe that. In the face of such concerns, we must do what we can. We must take any reasonable measure we can to support and extend our fellow citizens' ability to influence their Parliament.
Motion No. 89 is such a reasonable measure. Its adoption by this House would be an eminently worthwhile investment in the democratic future of our country at a time when real evidence of good faith by elected politicians would be welcomed by the Canadian people.
To adopt motion No. 89 would be good for democracy. It would be good for Parliament. It would be good for Canada.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip; Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is not common for Whips in our system to participate in parliamentary debates. It is not against the rules but it is not something that we do often. Certainly it is something that I would not do if in fact this particular private members' motion was to be coming to a vote.
There is a responsibility related to votes that goes with the Whip's job. We have been trying in the spirit of parliamentary reform to make sure that Private Members' Business is conducted by private members for private members. There is a distinction between votable motions and non-votable motions.
If it were votable then our side on every one of those occasions since I became Whip after the 1988 election has never had a Whip on any private members' motion that came to a vote. I would hate to provide a signal that was different.
I have spent a few hours of my life, over close to 13 years in this Chamber, and at various times have had responsibilities related to the rules of the Chamber and have had occasion to read those rules for all of their significance on a number of occasions. I felt compelled when I saw this particular motion to rise and express

some objection to what I was reading about in terms of the motion itself and what I was hearing in terms of the speech of my colleague from across the way.
This is a funny place. One can ask oneself why do Canadians lose confidence in it? They watch a hockey game and there are rules to a hockey game. They expect them to be the same from one game to the next. In this place it seems to people they are not the same. We have a set of rules and people do not obey them.
I simply say to the member: When you enter into the business of changing rules, do so with some trepidation. I realize he has only been in this Chamber about three years or maybe a little more than three years. It takes a long time to understand the rules of this place and the nuances and it takes a lot of effort.
To say one has a great idea to change the rules and to be reading a text about rule changes in the Chamber is a bit of an anomaly. One of the basic rules is that we really should not read what it is we say in this Chamber. This is a Chamber for debate. It is not a Chamber for reading texts which may have been created by the member or by someone else.
If one enters into the rule debate, one should be really careful to try to obey the rules as they exist as one petitions for a change in the rules. Years ago, in 1979, when I was a new member and we lost the confidence vote and we were back in an election in 1980, we brought forward a budget that created what the Canadian Council on Social Development called the fairest budget to poor people in the decade of the seventies. The NDP moved a motion to turf it out. They voted for the motion and they did turf it out. Yet we had heard so much rhetoric for so many days and so many months about how they cared about poor people and the fairness for poor people. At the very first opportunity to grab for power they turned their backs on the poor people. Under the guise of democracy, it is bringing forward one of the most expensive undertakings that I have seen brought forward in this Chamber.
We are talking about the need to create something in the order of one million signatures. If you have deep pockets with lots of money, you can hire firms like all those American firms that deal with petitions. You can go out and hire them to advance any cause you want. There is no way the poor people of this country could
Private Members' Business
gather one million signatures. They do not have the money. You are trying to turn the legislative dominance of this Chamber over to people with thick wallets. That runs counter to what I think my life has stood for, and what I think the lives of many members on this side have stood for. Their lives have stood for a sense of justice and fairness for everybody. To advance a set of rules which require a lot of money for people to exercise them seems like a bit of a contradiction between what is said and what members do.
On this side of the House we have to exercise a sense of responsibility. If we want rule changes affecting the role of private members, one of the tragedies is the number of motions and bills put forward by private members which are not well thought out. The wording which is inherent in them is not really responsible.
This is a classic example of somebody who is in love with an idea which may have come out of a fiction book or something. It would change the rules of this Chamber. Therefore, if you are a responsible parliamentarian, you must accept the responsibility for making propositions that use the time of this Chamber, propositions that are sensible and which will enable us to proceed in a reasonable fashion.
The member started off his speech by trying to ding government members for what they did about an aircraft maintenance contract. That was popular. The NDP premier of the province of Manitoba got all the headlines by saying that this government was really a terrible government because of that maintenance contract.
I am sitting here, poor little old me who tries to do a little bit of research before I reach a conclusion, and I ask: "Should we be repairing those airplanes today in St. Louis, Missouri and putting all the jobs in St. Louis, Missouri or were we right as a government to bring those jobs to Canada?" I look at de Havilland and I look at Canadair and Bristol and I say: "You know, the common characteristics of those two consortiums is that they are really healthy. In a time of recession they are doing very well. They do not take any more taxpayers' dollars". Canadair used to receive a subsidy of $1 billion and plus. It does not get a subsidy any more. However, there are 25 or 30 per cent more people working there with higher salaries and a better standard of living. Go to Winnipeg and look at Bristol. Again, it is the same picture, I think

Private Members' Business
there are almost 50 per cent more employees working at Bristol.
Yet, it was a bad decision. Somehow or other this government which brought the jobs back to Canada and helped two companies to expand and provide more jobs for more people committed a terrible sin.
If we were dependent on this petition mechanism, do you think it would have been any problem to get 5 per cent of voters, those who read the headlines, to sign a petition saying that the decision was wrong, to create enough political heat there on the street on the basis of little information, on misinformation and cause Parliament to do something with only 18 people out of 300 allowed to speak in three hours?
That is what this motion says: three hours, 18 people. This motion says that in four provinces, if you happen to be lucky enough to live in Ontario, Quebec, Alberta or British Columbia, you could create a petition in your province and cause this Parliament to do something. However if you lived in one of the other six, in Saskatchewan, Manitoba or P.E.I., you could not do that. You would have to go out and gather signatures in some other place.
I look at the time and those who are watching will realize that 10 minutes has gone by already. What if the petition was to eliminate income tax? Do you think there is any big trick in getting people to sign to eliminate income tax? However a responsible group must have a replacement. You cannot borrow your way into prosperity. You cannot borrow money forever. You cannot just do popular things that are will-o'-the-wisp. You have to make responsible decisions and take the heat.
You have to say: "No, we will not repair those jets in St. Louis; we will bring them back to Canada and create more jobs across this country in Winnipeg, Montreal, and Edmonton. If people think we are making a mistake we will listen to them carefully, we will listen to their logic. However, we will make the decision, we will be responsible and then history will tell us it was not such a bad decision after all. It was a pretty good one."
Think how unpopular the GST was. It was so unpopular that the group who promised to bring it in was elected with a majority government and those who promised not
to do it were defeated. This group says that free trade was such a terrible mistake. This group says it believes in democracy but the member who says we will have a democratic petition is still fighting the free trade issue.
He ran against it in the election but the party that was in favour of it was elected. That is what democracy is all about.
You submit something to the people from time to time, give them the responsibility of picking their representatives. Then you charge those representatives with the responsibility of making tough decisions, responsible decisions, not being ruled by will-o'-the-wisp popularity at that moment but making the tough decisions which over time make this world a better place for our children, our grandchildren, ourselves, and our parents.
That is what this is about. To change our rules to accommodate the people with lots of money in this country, to give them special control of this place is something I could never, ever support.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate the hon. member for Edmonton East on his very able presentation and introduction of his motion. As usual his speech was articulate, very carefully worded and most enjoyable. He has a great facility with the tongue.
He obviously wrote well and I congratulate him on that. He chose his words very carefully and I congratulate him on that.
I recognize that the hon. member for Calgary West has pointed out that one of the very important rules of this House is that you are not to read in debate. The purpose is to make speeches extemporaneous. However, there are so many members who choose to read that-
The Prime Minister, too.

The Prime Minister as well. There are members who do choose to read a great deal, and I think it is a matter of some regret. However that is the way it is. Unfortunately we seem to have allowed that rule to fall into desuetude. I suspect that if the rule were in force, our debates would be far more lively.
I think that many of the speeches would be much shorter and we would find that business would be conducted in a speedier fashion. I am sure that would please the government members and it would also give members of the opposition an opportunity to say what is
February 6, 1992

on their minds instead of spouting things they have considered and written down over a prolonged period.
For one reason or another the rule is not enforced. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary would want to address that issue in the house management committee of which he is the distinguished chairman, and then maybe something would come of it.
However, that is not the purpose of today's debate. What we are discussing is the proposal of the hon. member for Edmonton East. I must say that while it is an interesting idea, I do not feel that I can agree with it.
What he has done with this proposal is suggest that the members of this House somehow give up their exclusive right to introduce bills to Parliament and have those bills foisted on the House by petition. That is what it really comes down to.
Unfortunately, while that principle in itself may not be objectionable, though I have doubts, I am prepared to concede the point that the mechanism for doing it, as has been pointed out by the hon. member for Calgary West, is fraught with difficulty. Specifically, it would exclude smaller provinces from being able to participate in the legislative scheme, as it is drawn. Also, it fails to consider the fact that members of this House are free to introduce bills and have them debated as the hon. member for Edmonton East has done with this motion today.
I think it is very helpful that we can do that.
I wish there were a little more time spent on private members' business. I think there is a need for change in the rules to allow for more time so that when private members' hour is cancelled, as it was yesterday and as it will be tomorrow, that time can be made up at another time, especially when the government benefits by reaping a bonanza of an extra hour of debate on its own legislation when that happens.
That aside, private members' business does provide an opportunity for individual members to introduce these bills and motions and have them discussed in the House. There is no reason in the world why a bill or motion cannot reflect petitions that are presented to us by our electors.
Many members have introduced bills and motions. For some statistics, on Wednesday's Order Paper there were
Private Members' Business
639 notices of motions introduced in this House during this session, similarly, in the same Order Paper there are over 300 bills of which notice has been given. There were 127 bills introduced in the course of this session which were all private members' bills, all introduced by private members for the purpose of debate and discussion in the House.
That is a sizeable number of bills, especially when you consider that very few of them come from government members. Generally, parliamentary secretaries are not introducing bills. It is done by opposition MPs or by members who are neither in cabinet nor parliamentary secretaries on the other side.
Consider the number of those excluded. I suggest that there is ample opportunity here for the public to have input very directly in the system subject to the statutory requirement that money bills must be introduced by cabinet ministers only because they require the royal recommendation.
My friend from Edmonton East has tried to get around that in a skilful wording of this rule, but I think he recognizes that the rules of the House of Commons cannot change the constitutional requirements. His rule is ineffective in so far as it would require His Excellency to advise that any bill be recommended to the House of Commons. In other words, His Excellency's recommendation is not a forgone conclusion nor could it be.
There is a British precedent, I recognize, for changes which would allow for the royal recommendation to come forward on a bill that has been approved at a certain stage in the House. As I say, there are ways we can look at changing the operation of private members' hour that would allow for more scope for private members and would allow for more time for discussion of private members' business.
The fact is that our rules, in my view, are adequate as presently constituted to allow members of the public to bring forward items they want discussed in so far as those items are legislative changes. That I think is what the hon. member is getting at.
Many of the petitions that come to this House deal with government policy on items that are not the subject of legislation and that may not be legislated for. They may object to the government's policy of appointing

Private Members' Business
somebody to a particular board or commission, and that is not something that is covered by a bill in this House. It can be changed by a bill in this House, but it would be a most unusual step to make such a change.
Similarly, the petitions may deal with bills that are already coming before the House and express opinion one way or the other, such as the GST petitions of which there were so many. I well recall day after day standing and presenting GST petitions, as did members of the New Democratic Party, all in opposition to that bill. The bill was here. It was discussed in the House, albeit for a limited time.
The fact is that petitions are not always ones that call for the introduction of new bills that have to be dealt with.
I find that when I am approached by constituents who want a new bill introduced in the House and discussed, if the bill is one that finds any favour with me at all, I am quite prepared to entertain the idea, have the bill drafted and set it down as one of my bills. I have about a dozen on the Order Paper at the moment.
The hon. member is free to do the same. With 295 members reflecting widely disparate constituencies and having widely different interests, it seems to me it is entirely possible for members of the public to find one member of this House who would be willing to introduce a bill on any given subject as a private members' bill and have it discussed in this place.
I do not think that is overly difficult.
Quite frankly, I think the hon. member in putting forward this motion is perhaps addressing an issue that has not been raised by the public and is not a public issue; that is that the public is somehow deprived of a right to have its grievances addressed in this House.
The weakness I perceive in our procedure, if any, and I think there is one, is that the hon. member is really trying to address the debatability or otherwise of a petition. I think what the hon. member is trying to suggest is that we need to discuss the content of a petition so that the grievance complained of in the petition is aired in this House. There are other ways of doing it. I suspect the hon. member was here earlier today and heard the discussion concerning the use of Standing Order 52, the emergency debate provision and
the suggestion that was made by his colleague, the hon. member for Kamloops, and myself.
I know the parliamentary secretary, the hon. member for Peace River, agreed in large measure with what we said. It was that need to use that rule more often to allow emergency debates to take place, as we are going to do this evening, in a way, on the constitutional matter; to allow the House to deal in a timely way with issues of public importance.
There is natural reluctance on the part of the government to do that because sometimes the issue is one that is cause for embarrassment for the government. If that is the case, the government does not want a public airing or discussion of the issue because it will look bad. Therefore, we have this reluctance on one side and the enthusiasm on the other, perhaps for partisan reasons, nevertheless, because of the importance of airing the discussion or airing the grievance that has arisen in the public mind.
This House could become more relevant if more debates of that kind took place. I think the petition road is too slow. By the time the signatures are gathered on the petitions and brought in here for debate or discussion, the issue may have become moot and of no interest to the general public.
For those reasons, and while I think the hon. member is to be commended for his efforts in drafting this lengthy motion, I think it is ill advised. If it were a votable motion, I would be inclined to vote against it, and I say so with some regret because I recognize the hon. member's great work in preparing this.
Mr. Albert Cooper (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House
of Commons): Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to take a few minutes to participate in this debate this afternoon.
I have to say I listened to the hon. member for Edmonton East with great care and as is his usual wont, he gave a very articulate, humorous and convincing argument.
When first I looked at this motion, I was a little struck by it because of my interest in procedure, and thought it was something worthy of pursuit. In spite of the hon. member's compelling arguments and his great rhetoric, having spent a little time on the motion I find it to be, I hesitate to use the word ridiculous, but certainly not one
February 6, 1992

of the more serious presentations that have come before this House of Commons.
I want to spend just a few minutes tonight talking about why I think this kind of motion would be a terrible disaster for us to exercise.
If we look at the beginning of his motion, he lays out two conditions under which petitions would become active items for debate here in this House of Commons. The first is that 3 per cent of Canadians who are eligible to vote, who signed a petition and had that petition presented in this House, would trigger a debate. In the cases of expenditure, 5 per cent of Canadians would be required.
The frightening thing about that is I recently saw a poll from the United States saying that a significant group of people, many more than 3 per cent, believed that Elvis Presley was still alive. Therefore, you can imagine the situation we face in the country. I do not think it would be difficult at all to find 3 per cent of people who believe in anything in this country.
Therefore, here we would be on a regular occasion faced with a debate in the House of Commons on anything from whether Elvis Presley is really dead or alive to who knows what.
My hon. friend argues that this would be a very difficult procedure to organize because it is difficult to get people to sign petitions.
That is not the case. I have to say that I have had some very interesting experiences with petitions and it is for that reason that I do not treat them seriously at all.
When I have received petitions, I have phoned people and I have said to them: "You signed this petition on this particular issue and I want to spend a few moments talking with you about it and its implications". Often they do not remember signing the petition, or once you spend more than about three or four minutes with them, you discover that they really did not know what the implications of that particular issue were.
What we want to create here is an opportunity for that issue to come into the House of Commons and to take up three hours of debate and possibly end up being a law. TTiat would be in an extreme circumstance and I do not
Private Members' Business
want to use an extreme argument to make the case, but it is a possibility because that is what the law provides.
The other thing that I find extremely intriguing about this particular option is the hon. member says: "You may only have one of these every once in a while, a very rare circumstance". I suggest, as my hon. friend from Calgary said a little while ago, that one does not know where these things are going to go when the doors are open. For example, I find it particularly intriguing that what would happen is once you had a petition signed by 3 per cent of the population, or 5 per cent if there is an expenditure, it would be tabled in the House of Commons. It would immediately go to the Chief Electoral Officer. The Chief Electoral Officer, within three weeks, has to report to Parliament.
In three weeks, by the hon. member's own calculations, it is up to the Chief Electoral Officer to verify roughly 530,000, 3 per cent or, in the case of 5 per cent,
880,000	signatures. This is going to create an incredible bureaucracy. This would be a wonderful job creator in the Public Service because what you would need is a huge set of machinery to verify every signature to make sure it is a valid one. Then you would have to turn around and make sure that person was an eligible signer, in other words, they were eligible to vote. Then you would have to cross-reference them to make sure that they did not sign it more than once. My goodness, who knows, you may be faced with two of these petitions in the Chief Electoral Officer's office at the same time.
What do you have to do? You would have to create the employment opportunities to make sure that this happens. It is a wonderful idea for job creation, but I am certain it is not a practical idea in terms of the Canadian public's desire to make sure that government expenditures are curtailed and not increased dramatically, particularly if the public felt it was unnecessary. I think that is a very serious flaw in this particular motion that the hon. member presents to this House.
The other thing I find very fascinating is that in our tradition there is quite a distinction between government and opposition. We have this huge aisle that, for the most part, separates us. We have many traditions and many rules that all respect that distinction. Where does the hon. member wish for this debate to take place? Is it in some special kind of House time? No, it is in

Private Member's Business
government time. It is the government that has been officially and duly elected by the people of Canada to form the government which has to set aside its agenda to provide for a vote or a debate from some 3 per cent of the population. The net result of that is three hours.
Three hours of debate does not sound like much, but it is an entire morning and in some cases it is virtually a whole day. There are several days, Wednesday for example, during which there are a total of six hours of debate. With some other things intervening into it, you would have five, down maybe to four or four and a half hours with Routine Proceedings and so on.
What is the bottom line? With each signed petition which must be debated in this House of Commons, all of a sudden you start seeing that you are looking at a significant amount of government time being taken by something that has nothing to do with the government, the government that was properly elected, and certainly is not part of its agenda.
The other thing that I wanted to reflect on for a couple of minutes was this very novel approach to the idea of the royal prerogative. Under our traditions it is the government that maintains that prerogative. It is the government that goes to the Governor General and seeks the consent, if I can describe it that way, to spend money.
It does it in a very tight balancing act. It says it is going to spend the money here because it is raising it in taxes here and it has constantly a balance of procedures. It has the budget, the estimates, all of which are carefully thought through. We all know how many days and weeks and hours go into the presentation of a budget in this House of Commons. Every group of expenditures is thought through with the greatest of care, because the use of our financial resources that we collect from the taxpayers of Canada is taken so seriously.
Now, all of a sudden, by simply having 5 per cent of Canadians sign a petition, you suddenly have a royal recommendation that comes right out of the blue and is not part of any question of taxation. It is an obligation. I want to read this particular section, it is in proposed 36.4(2):
-the Minister who is a Member of Parliament designated for this purpose by the Ministry shall seek the recommendation of the Governor General for the Bill or Motion, and thereafter that Minister shall be deemed to be the sponsor of the Bill or mover of the Motion in the House, and shall be responsible for securing a seconder.
The minister does not take into account the question of raising the revenues. There is no responsibility in terms of budgetary balance. It is simply a minister now being instructed to waltz down and get a royal recommendation.
Today we face a deficit problem in this country in which every dollar we are looking to spend on individual programs is a dollar that has to be sought carefully, balanced carefully. All of those considerations have to be taken into account and the net result of this is that we could somehow circumvent all of that.
The other thing I find extremely intriguing is a whole new concept again. We know on our orders, the way they are now, if a bill is not completed by the time of the ending of a session, it dies. This one wants to say it can carry over. It is not a practical solution. It is not a practical idea.
I understand the member's interest in participatory democracy, if I can call it that, but the reality is that this is cumbersome, bureaucratic, expensive and I think totally subverts the whole process that we have in this country of looking after our own expenditures.

speechtext: February 6, 1992
A motion to adjourn the House under Standing Order 38 deemed to have been moved.

Madam Speaker, I rise to address this evening the disastrous fishing season in Newfoundland last year that focused attention on the five years of plunder of Grand Banks fish stocks by foreign fleets operating outside the 200-mile economic zone. While Newfoundland trawlers remained alongside, European boats stole over $100 million worth of our groundfish.
The government has been telling the fishing community that nothing could be done about this plundering. That is what it is; it is plundering the nose and tail of the bank because international law has fixed the limit at 200 miles. Nothing can be done about it, it says, until there is an international agreement that extends the adjacent coastal state's fishing zone to the edge of the Continental Shelf.
This opinion in my mind reveals a fundamental lack of understanding of how international fisheries and marine law has developed. I have had 20 years experience in marine and international law and I can say that it differs fundamentally from internal state law in that the unilateral action I am suggesting tonight is recognized as a legitimate means by which law can develop.
I want to give three instances. The first one was the 1948 Truman proclamation whereby the United States laid claim to the sub-sea mineral resources off its continental shelf. In 1970 there was a series of unilateral declarations whereby Iceland extended its fisheries jurisdiction out to 200 miles at a time when the territorial sea was 12 miles.
In the case of Iceland, the International Court of Justice in 1974 recognized the acceptance of preferential rights especially for this coastal state in a situation of "dependency upon coastal fisheries for its livelihood". The situation of Iceland appeared as one of exceptional dependence on its fishery resources.
Adjournment Debate
Then again there is the Canadian precedent in 1977 when Canada decided to take unilateral action-we took it in 1977-to create a 200-mile economic zone of jurisdiction. It is ironic that the need for this action was intensified by the threats of overfishing by Spain and Portugal.
This is not to say, even using those three examples, that all unilateral action is valid in international law. If a state initiates action that is ludicrous and selfish, then it is going to be referred to as piracy and the state will not be able to stand on their ground.
To be legitimate, a unilateral state action must be grounded in an administrative scheme that is in accordance with international law. I submit the three precedents I gave indicate where dependence on the resource is a very relevant issue. It has to be fair.
Another important thing is that the unilateral declaration is not enough unless it is backed up by state enforcement. In other words, the coastal state must assert its sovereignty and be able to do so over the waters in question. I suggest we need to beef up the means to be able to detect, identify, recognize, search, seize, arrest, try and prosecute transgressors.
If the political will is present, Canada can legally under international law unilaterally extend our fishing limit to the edge of the Continental Shelf. Of course any such move has to be accompanied by a global campaign to explain the reason for such action which given the devastating effect of the rampant overfishing outside our 200-mile limit, should not be too difficult.
I will be persistent in promoting this idea until the government gets off its asymmetrical and ineffective approach to overfishing and puts words, thoughts and ideas into serious action.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I must confess to the hon. member opposite that I was expecting him to be discussing the question that he had put in this House on October 22. At least that was what I was prepared for. None of what he mentioned today was mentioned in his question or in the preamble of the question of that day. The central part of his question that day was on job creation and that is what I prepared.

February 6, 1992
Adjournment Debate
I want to make sure the hon. member understands and ensures his constituents that this overfishing has been of major concern to the Government of Canada. Ambassador Gherson has been working with the European community and various parts of the North Atlantic Fisheries Council. At NAFO we have been working very hard on that.
As well, last month the minister made a major address in London dealing with the very problems that the hon. member is drawing to our attention. He said that unless they start to follow the rules and the suggested limits put down, that unless all members participate, Canada would be forced to try to endeavour to take unilateral action such as the member opposite has outlined.
However, I think the negotiating table must be tried first to make sure we have a reply before we attempt to do what the hon. member opposite is suggesting. I thank him again for bringing this matter to our attention.

Madam Speaker, the fisheries industry on the west coast also has problems.
If it were not for changes in the UI legislation which meant that the workers had to put in a full 680 hours to qualify for UI as used to be the case, then there would not be that problem.
It is quite conceivable that the workers in the fishing industry in B.C. could put in a total of 680 hours at a 40-hour week. That is 17 weeks. Often they have to work around the clock if the fish are coming in fast. If the rules were changed so that they got credit for UI on the basis of the number of hours worked, I would not be here today presenting this problem.
In 1990 there was a program that helped them, the Emergency Response Program. It provided employment. More than that, it provided for projects that were beneficial to the industry and to the communities. It helped British Columbia. It helped the people by giving them enough stamps so they qualified for UI.
That program was supported by the fisheries committee this year as something that should be renewed. It was supported by the labour committee where a resolution was passed urging the government to act. In response to questions ministers indicated support for it, but so far the program has not been delivered.
What I am asking is that the government reconsider its position and bring this program in again. Not only does it provide employment for the people who need a little more time to get their UI, but as I say it brought into effect beneficial projects in communities. It helped the industry by developing stream clearing projects. It was something that helped preserve a billion dollar industry that is important to British Columbia and to Canada.
I urge the government to respond positively, to take another look at its decision not to support it this year, and to bring it into effect for this season.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, again I want to acknowledge the hon. member opposite and his dedication to bringing this matter to the attention of the House at this time.
He will recall when members of the fishing industry were down here and asking for us to have a similar program, they likened it to what was happening on the east coast. The Emergency Response Program was what they were alluding to. They felt they should have something similar for British Columbia.
However, we had to point out to them at that time that their circumstances were entirely different from what was happening on the east coast. The east coast had been hampered by ice conditions under which they could not get their gear into the water and then very low catches later on in the summer. Some areas had less than 50 per cent of the previous year's catch.
Within British Columbia the fisheries experienced a period of structural changes. That is what is happening in British Columbia. We are challenged to deal with the technological changes that are taking place in the fisheries. The stocks are certainly on the average of what they have been over the last four or five years; there has certainly not been a shortage of fish.
It is just with the gear changes that have taken place and the number of people who are fishing, they can do it in a much shorter time frame. We have people, as the hon. member has pointed out, who are working very long hours in the fishing plants, almost round the clock and yet only being credited with a single day's work. Whether or not this is the right way to go is something that has to
February 6, 1992

be seriously considered and has been looked at as well. I thank the hon. member for again winging this matter to our attention.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted again to stand in the House today regarding a question I put late in 1991 on East Timor. It is not the first time that I have made serious attempts in this House to get an answer to questions regarding the tragic situation as it is in East Timor today.
At that time the Secretary of State for External Affairs had recently announced the suspension of $30 million in aid to Indonesia because of the November 12 massacre at Dili. In addition, all other aid projects were subject to review. The suspended aid is said to comprise new projects which will be put on hold until the minister decides otherwise.
I could be cynical and suggest that the minister will wait until the media goes away before deciding to resume business as usual with Indonesia. We are still waiting for specific details surrounding the suspended aid and what process it must go through before it is either reinstated or cut permanently.
However we do know that the three projects which have been suspended include: (1) a program to train water resource engineers, (2) a program to promote private sector linkages between Canada and Indonesia and (3) a program aimed at helping the Indonesian government modernize its bureaucracy. Although these are hardly the kinds of programs which will rock the Indonesian government to its core, it is encouraging to see that it is not the grassroots kind of aid which goes directly to helping people who are innocent of their government's activities.
The real issue to which I want a response is this: When will this government finally support United Nations Security Council resolutions 384 and 389 which call for the withdrawal of Indonesian troops from East Timor? It is a simple question, yet the government has consistently refused to answer it every time my colleagues or I raise it in this House. There should be no question as to how Canada should be dealing with this situation.
Adjournment Debate
The best word to describe the situation which the people of East Timor have endured since the 1975 invasion and subsequent occupation by Indonesia is holocaust. Up to one-third of the population of East Timor, 200,000 people, have been killed in battle, in concentration camps, or through famine and disease. Yet the Canadian government has ignored the carnage and has ignored the actions of the vast majority of nations in the international community which have outright condemned the actions of Indonesia.
The United Nations has passed resolution after resolution calling for Indonesia to withdraw and for the right of the East Timorese to self-determination, and what has Canada done? It has voted against UN resolutions calling for self-determination. It has lobbied to have the issue removed from the UN agenda. This is unfathomable to me. It is unbelievable. It is an international embarrassment to the Canadian people who are decent and caring and want Canada to help put an end to such slaughter.
Instead of doing what is right, this government has continued to build bigger and bigger trade links with Indonesia to the point that it is now petrified of jeopardizing the precious balance of trade. If the government would listen to the Canadian people, it would know that they do not want the blood of the East Timorese on their conscience.
We have a moral responsibility to end this bloodshed. I would hate to think that the Caanadian government is ignoring the plight of the East Timorese because there is no economic advantage to do otherwise.
The Secretary of State for External Affairs said earlier today that she was pleased that the UN was considering sending an investigative unit to examine the situation in East Timor.
Will she go the extra distance and instruct or advise the Canadian delegation to the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva to push for Indonesian withdrawal from East Timor?
I ask this on behalf of the East Timorese, on behalf of all caring, thinking Canadians, on behalf of people in other countries who might be helped if this government would stop being hypocritical and inconsistent and live up to its rhetoric on human rights.

Adjournment Debate
Will the minister finally give assurances to the House that Canada will immediately support UN Security Council resolutions 384 and 389 which call for the removal of Indonesian troops?
Thank you very much, Madam Speaker. You have been very patient.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in reply to the member from Nepean on the various questions, I would like to assure the hon. member that the Canadian government has taken action with regard to Indonesia.
I can say that the Secretary of State for External Affairs conveyed Canada's dismay of the shootings during meetings with the Indonesian Foreign Minister in Seoul on November 13, 1991 a few hours after the news of the killing of the East Timorese had come to light.
Canadian concerns were also expressed to the Indonesian authorities by the Canadian ambassador in Djakarta and to the Indonesian ambassador in Canada. These Canadian concerns were also raised during the session of the third committee of the current United Nations General Assembly.
On December 9, 1991, the Secretary of State for External Affairs announced:
1.	Canada has suspended the approval of new development projects for Indonesia in the order of $30 million.
2.	Canada has decided to give an immediate grant of $150,000 to the International Committee of the Red Cross for humanitarian assistance in East Timor.
3.	Canada will take into account the results of the Indonesian commission of inquiry set up to investigate the shootings and the action of the Indonesian government in the context of the current broader aid review.
Canada is encouraged by the interim report of the Indonesian commission of inquiry and the response of the Indonesian government in taking prompt action on a number of the recommendations in the report.
Canada does, however, have serious concerns about the human rights situation in Indonesia and will continue to watch the developments in this area veiy closely in
consultation with like-minded countries in the context of the United Nations.
Canada welcomes the visit of Foreign Minister Alatas in February which will provide an opportunity for further discussions on the human rights situation and the Canadian Development Assistance Program in Indonesia.

speakeroldname: Mr. Francis G. LeBIanc (Cape Breton Highlands- Canso):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I welcome the opportunity today to return to a question that I raised in this House on November 18 of last year concerning a decision by CN Rail to sell its railway line from Truro to Sydney, Nova Scotia.
At that time, I urged the government, specifically the Minister of Transport, to intervene to block this sale which was causing great uncertainty to all of the major customers and major industrial users all along the line from Turo to Sydney, Nova Scotia.
Unfortunately so far the government has taken no action. Today the Senate committee on transportation and communications has begun three days of public hearings on this issue, which is of vital concern to the economy and to the people of eastern Nova Scotia.
The Senate committee will hear from some of the main customers located along this railway line, customers which together employ some 7,000 people and which constitute the core of the industrial base of the 250 miles of railway line.
The committee will hear from Mr. Tom Hall, the president and general manager of Stora Forest Industries in Point Tipper, which is the largest user of the line on which more than 2,000 people depend in the pulp mill and in the woodlands operation.
The committee will also hear from Sydney Steel Corporation and the Cape Breton Development Corporation, both of which are major users of the line and are pillars of the industrial Cape Breton economy. The committee will also hear from Scott Paper Company of Abercrombie in Pictou county which is another major user of this line.
I do not pretend to anticipate what these witnesses will say in their presentations, but I do know from extensive conversations with senior management at Stora Forest Industries that they are very concerned and that their

continued operation depends vitally on a secure rail line service to their plant and that the decision by CN has created great uncertainty, not only to the continued operation of the plant but to further expansion which is vital to the future of the area.
Let me quote one of the witnesses who appeared before this committee today, the minister of transportation and communications of Nova Scotia, the Hon. Ken Stretch, who came up from Halifax to make his point before the committee. The minister of transportation says, and I will simplify the presentation which is an excellent one: "The province of Nova Scotia insists that rail service to Sydney must be maintained. The only way to guarantee that is if the federal government meets its constitutional responsibility to maintain essential rail service. We have some very specific concerns about the viability of a short line operation on this line, which is what CN is proposing to replace this line with".
The decision by CN has caused great concern to all residents and all industrial users in eastern Nova Scotia. In fact, our concern is one of disbelief that CN would actually propose at this time to sell this vital piece of infrastructure and that this government would refuse to exercise its mandate to intervene and prevent this vital piece of infrastructure from being sold off.
To conclude, while the government may try to avoid its responsibility in this matter, it cannot. The land on which the rail line is located is owned by the Government of Canada and it will have to give its approval at some point through an Order in Council if that sale is to go through. Therefore, why not intervene, prevent the sale now and assure the future of this economy.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the government believes that CN must be a fiscally responsible manager in order to remain competitive and ensure financial viability in the transportation marketplace. In this light the Sydney-Truro line has been examined and it has been found that while the line continues to be profitable it is still a light density route.
CN feels that a short line operator can maintain and in all probability enhance the traffic it is currently carrying. CN is not diminishing the importance of the line with
Adjournment Debate
this proposal. Indeed, CN recognizes that the continued operation of the line is important precisely because it provides traffic for the main line between Halifax and central Canada.
The more traffic volume that can be generated on the core network, the lower the operating cost. This in turn allows the railway to be more competitive for additional traffic. It is very important to CN that the short line operator selected be one that will continue rail service for existing and hopefully, new customers.
The section process that CN will subject all bidders to has this objective in mind. CN is committed to ensuring that there is the necessary financial capability to undertake the acquisition and operation of the line.
In the hon. member's question of last November, he referred to the confidential nature of the process. The specific content of each bid must be treated confidentially in order to protect the integrity of a competitive bid process. This is standard practice.
CN has been open about the steps in the selection of a buyer and also about the criteria that will be used in each step.
The short line concept offers benefits for shippers and receivers. It is encouraging that the potential of a short line operation for the Truro-Sydney line has drawn a promising level of response. It is an expression of faith in this exciting railway concept and in the promise of Cape Breton.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, last October 25 I rose in this House to speak of the issue of unfair and unjust salary increases given to presidents and high-ranking officials of Crown corporations and government agencies. At that time I spoke of the $131,250 salary increase given to the president of Canada Post. That was the salary increase on top of the salary that the individual was already receiving.
You could argue that government has the discretion to give whatever salary increase it wishes to this individual. I do not claim that that is so, but even if it were so, it would be unfair if that benefit were accorded to one individual when everyone else's salary has been frozen. That is in fact what happened.

February 6, 1992
Adjournment Debate
If that is not bad enough, I want to bring to your attention, as I did at that time, the case of a 65-year old widow in my riding who was a rural mail contractor. Her name is Huguette Perrier, 65 years old, a widow who delivered the mail on the rural route. She was unceremoniously dumped by Canada Post after she and her husband-she took over the mail run when her husband died-had been delivering the mail in the community of Dalkeith for a period of 25 years. Do you know why she was dumped, Madam Speaker? Because Canada Post gave the contract to someone else for $1,500 less.
To save $1,500 this person was fired. This person has no job. At the same time, within months, this government was giving a $131,000 increase to the president of Canada Post who already makes a quarter of a million dollars a year in salary. The justification given for all of that by Canada Post boggles the mind.
I have letters here that were written to me by various individuals. I wrote to the minister about this, but of course the minister did not reply other than telling me that he had referred the letter to Canada Post, failing to recognize that under the Financial Administration Act he has the authority to direct the Crown corporation, as the minister does under that act, and as my colleagues all know.
Canada Post says in its letters the following: "I am sure that you will appreciate that Canada Post must operate in a fiscally responsible manner when selecting suppliers and contractors". No one is against motherhood but the facts are different. There is nothing fiscally irresponsible about keeping an employee that has been with you for 25 years when the employee is not even asking for a salary increase. That is just sound, humane management.
Anyone in the private sector who is trying to do what Canada Post is doing would be severely criticized on the floor of the House of Commons if we found out about it. But this is a Crown corporation doing, not what a Crown corporation and agency of the government should be doing, but worse than what any one of us would tolerate from the private sector. That is what is so bad about this.
In closing, I do not object to the fact that when someone has a rural mail contract and the person is asking for an increase, it should be subject to tender in order to get that increase. But when someone wants to merely keep their job at the existing price and they are tendered out and lose their job, well then something is hopelessly wrong.

speakeroldname: Mr. Michel Champagne (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Forestry):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I listened very carefully to what was said by the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, and I was surprised he was critical of the salary paid the director general of Canada Post, especially when we realize that from the deficit-ridden corporation it was in 1984, costing taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars, Canada Post has now become a profitable Crown corporation. It takes competent people to do that sort of thing. The current president,- Madam Speaker, may not be perfect, but when we came to power in 1984, he was given a mandate to make the Canada Post Corporation a going concern. He fulfilled that mandate, and he did so remarkably well.
Remember, Madam Speaker, when Canada Post was the laughing stock of this country? Postal services were a joke. Everybody was saying that besides paying for the stamps, they had to go to the competition to make sure the mail would be delivered on time.
Madam Speaker, when we appoint people to boards of directors, when we appoint directors to turn a situation around that was bad for the taxpayers and bad in terms of the services offered by Canada Post, we assume these people will have to make decisions that will not always please the customer, considering why they were appointed in the first place.
In this respect, Madam Speaker, if we consider Mr. Landers' salary, it appears to be on a level with remuneration for the same type of work in the private sector. We are not ahead of the private sector in this respect. We are taking its lead. What Canada Post is being asked to do is exactly what other corporations are being asked to do, which is to make a profit. This has been achieved, and we owe Mr. Landers and his team a vote of thanks, and we hope they keep up the good work, for the benefit of Canadians and Quebecers.
