speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Science
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to participate in these discussions in order that we can communicate to the House of Commons and record in Hansard some of the comments that have been made to us as members of Parliament about the proposed changes to the Constitution and the process which has been implemented to try to make them.
What comes out loud and clear in the letters I have received is that Canada is a relative youngster compared to the nations of Europe. We are celebrating 125 years of nationhood this year, while England, France, Italy, and Greece can measure their ages in thousands of years.
Yet, despite our short history and a small population, Canada and Canadians have achieved much together and have built much of which all of us can be justifiably proud. Canadian men and women have built a society considered to be one of the fairest and freest in the world. Believe it or not, though we are young we are also one of the oldest functioning democracies in the world. We are the eighth largest economy in the world today, and that economic strength has enabled us to develop some of the most advanced social programs of any nation. Indeed, Canada's medicare system is still studied by other countries, including the United States.
Outside of our own country we are considered to be one of the greatest countries in the world, not in terms of our military strength but in terms of who and what we are. In a recent United Nations report which surveyed 160 nations, Canada was the second most desirable country in which to live. Millions of people would do anything to move to Canada and we have long waiting lines at many of our embassies around the world. The
The Constitution
dispossessed and people fleeing oppression see Canada as a beacon of hope in an otherwise dimly lit world.
Our society happens to be a model that other nations are keen to emulate. Our tolerance of diversity has enabled Canada to avoid the kind of racial tensions that affect other nations. We are gradually learning how to honour the contribution and special place of our aboriginal people. We are recognized and respected as Canadians, and as a country known as Canada, for the constructive role we play in world affairs. The skills and ideas of Canadians are second to none. The ingenuity of individuals has made Canada a world leader in many fields and I mention but two: transportation and telecommunications.
For example, we were the third nation in the world to put a satellite into space. I might add that Canada continues to maintain a commitment to the search for knowledge through the exploration of space. On January 22, 1992, the second Canadian went into space. Dr. Roberta Bondar from Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, became the first Canadian woman to orbit the earth, returning eight days later following a successful mission.
Canada has once again proven its excellence in the field of scientific research. Just yesterday it was announced that a team of Canadian scientists led by Dr. Robert Korneluk of the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario played a central role in the recent discovery of the gene responsible for myotonic muscular dystrophy, an incurable muscle disease which strikes young adults.
In recent years Canadian scientists have been at the forefront of several major genetic discoveries, including the discovery of a defective gene that causes cystic fibrosis.
Canada's first prime minister, Sir John A. Macdonald, said: "Canada is a great country and shall become one of the greatest in the universe if we preserve it. We shall sink into adversity and insignificance if we suffer it to be broken".
Let us all take up the challenge of Sir John A. Let us all try, as a parliament in particular, to preserve a truly great country.
As a united country we have the seventh largest economy in the world. A divided country would have significantly less economic clout and leverage. Further,

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
as one Canada we have a place at many of the international bargaining tables. For example, Canada is a member of the G-7 economic powers. We are a member of the Council on Security and Co-operation in Europe. We are also a member of NATO and sit at the table of the World Bank.
Both foreign and domestic investors are less likely to invest in Canada if they are uncertain about its political or constitutional future.
International uncertainty also has a direct impact on interest rates, the value of our dollar, and domestic inflation.
The realities of the new global economy are these: competition is fierce and it is getting more so every day; technology and innovation are forcing everyone to adapt more quickly and more often; the new knowledge-based economy demands a higher educated and trained work force; and international capital markets react swiftly to any of these uncertainties.
Over the last few years the government has undertaken many initiatives, often very unpopular ones, to begin the process of modernizing Canada's economy and eliminating the structural barriers to future prosperity.
In the face of continuing change, more needs to be done. However, we can only undertake it by making the fundamental constitutional changes that will ensure Canada's continuing success while at the same time reflecting our national aspirations. The ultimate proposals will not be acceptable unless they provide the means for the federal government to maintain certain national standards in the interests of all Canadians. For example, health care must be accessible to all Canadians and pensions should be portable across the country.
Finally, Parliament and the federal government are the only political institutions in this country that represent all of Canada. Therefore, the federal government must and will play a vigorous role in articulating and defending the vital Canadian interests. We will not be a referee between competing regions or interests in the process.
Within the framework of a strong and united Canada there is a lot of room for constitutional modification. Even with constitutional change we must and will remain a strong and united Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to take advantage of this opportunity tonight to spend a bit of time to reflect on some of the comments that my constituents have had to say about the current debate in Canada about national unity and about our country.
I am pleased to take advantage of this time to talk about two specific initiatives that I have been doing in my own riding, in fact, one particular initiative on this issue which we announced today.
First of all, I think some congratulations are in order for the two House leaders who have arranged for this debate. Obviously, there will be a great deal more debate likely in March when the joint parliamentary committee releases its report and there should be other occasions for this kind of debate.
It is important that all of us from all our different perspectives have the opportunity to report on what we are hearing from our constituents and of course to enumerate and talk about what we see as to how this debate is shaping up.
It is important that all members share with others what they been hearing during this intense and sometimes confusing debate about the future of our country. My constituents are probably like many others. They find in many cases that the debate has gone on much too long.
Perhaps it is time to move quickly to make a decision about Canada, about the nature of our Confederation and of course, to get on to deal with some of the many important economic issues that we have in the country now. In particular, I am thinking of employment in my part of British Columbia, in the Prince George region, about trade, and other issues like those.
They are cognizant of the need obviously to come to grips with the whole constitutional debate and see just what direction Parliament and Canada is going in. In my travels through my riding basically in the last six months or so, I have heard comments from people about the need for a united Canada, a debate about the role of Quebec, a vigorous debate that many of my colleagues from Quebec would expect from western Canada, but a very positive debate as well.

I do not think members from Quebec should necessarily think that everything they see in the news necessarily reflects all the views of people from western Canada. I suppose most are trying to find a way to make Canada a better place and I, for one, think it is a better place with Quebec in Confederation.
We have debated and in my various community meetings we have talked about the Senate. We really need the Senate. Can it really reflect the regions as it is supposed to do? I find interesting just as a side-note that many of those who are promoting the Senate, having an elected Senate, the so-called Triple-E Senate, are often the same people who want to cut government programs. Yet here we are trying to create a whole new level of government.
My own party, as you know, has long been a supporter of the position to abolish the Senate, that we do not need it. That policy of course, in light of the debate today has taken on a new approach and a new look. We are not hard and fast. I do not know if anybody can be that way these days, to see what kind of suggestions Canadians have about what the Senate should be and do.
My constituents are also particularly interested and concerned about seeing a resolution as quickly as possible on the whole question of aboriginal self-government. I think that is an important and a critical issue and one that I hope will be dealt with. It must be dealt with in this so-called round, this Canada round.
We have all been doing our part. All members of Parliament in a manner of ways have been adding to this debate from their own particular points of view. I have held my own community meetings. People have come to those meetings to discuss what is going on with the constitutional debate.
I was even pleased, some say brave, to have the hon. member for Chambly come to a public meeting in Prince George to discuss from his perspective the role of Quebec in Confederation. We had a good discussion with that member and I was quite pleased that he was able to come and discuss his vision of Canada.
I am also pleased to get the information out to people. One of the things that I found really frightening after the collapse of the Meech Lake accord was really how little information there was around about our country's own
The Constitution
Constitution. While the government could spend some $14 million advertising the goods and services tax, you had to look pretty far to find out exactly what the Constitution of the country was all about.
That effort has been made this time around. The lesson was obviously learned. More information has to be sent out to Canadians about the constitutional debate.
I have made an effort in my area for anyone who is interested. I welcome anyone who is watching tonight who might be interested to write to me.
My office sends out monthly a detailed package of comments from all points of view on the whole debate. Not just comments from the New Democratic Party leader, the hon. member for Yukon, but also speeches from the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, columns and debates from people representing a sovereignist point of view in Quebec so that, at the very least, people in my area will have the information to make a valued judgment about this particular debate.
In fact the results are showing by the very articulate and thoughtful letters I have been receiving from people who have been reading through this information. Some very excellent comments have been made on the Senate, on referenda and it is adding to the debate.
I encourage other members where they can to do that. There is no harm in spreading information about what all of us are saying. Of course, I welcome anybody who is watching to write to me. I would be pleased to put them on that particular list.
The other initiative I mentioned at the start of my comments is that we have made an announcement today in my riding for Prince George-Bulkley Valley. I have asked students at the college in Prince George, the college at New Caledonia to volunteer to put together a constitutional forum.
They will be breaking into teams to represent and present the pros and cons and the different arguments around the government's proposals. This will not be just a sell job for the government's proposals. We want to hear what people's opinions are on all sides of the debate, of the different components of this particular package and indeed, some of the components that are not mentioned.

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
We have scheduled the forum for February 29, a Saturday. It will go all day and it is open to the public to hear the debate from students and to participate as well. I will be ensuring that a record of all the discussions and comments is made and that it will be passed on to the Prime Minister, the premiers and all members of this House and the Senate.
It is important that we have a user-friendly approach to this debate so that people do have an opportunity to have their input.
Of course, the timing will probably be good. The report from the joint committee will be out the day before. There will be plenty to talk about. Of course, this whole debate about our Constitution does not just end on February 28. Nor does it end on Canada Day, nor I hope does it end in October of this year. Obviously, the debate about our country and the Constitution of Canada will probably go on forever.
If there is any one message we have to get across to all Canadians it is that the debate about our country is not just a debate about words on paper. It has to be a debate about what Canada means and what we have to do is to frame that debate so that all Canadians can feel they can participate.
Again, I want to congratulate all members of the House for having organized this debate. It will be an important one. I will be listening and watching carefully.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to discuss what is probably the most important issue facing Canada today. Even as I say that, I am extremely conscious of the fact that both our economic difficulties and the constitutional issue must be given an equal amount of attention during the course of the next few months.
In many ways, as I will refer to later in my comments, those two issues are very closely intertwined. It goes without saying that those we would like to attract to our country to provide us with investment dollars, those we would like to join with us in trading relationships want to know before they do so what is to be the future of Canada.
The issue which is before us is very difficult, very complicated and very emotional. I think the fact that it is so emotional makes it even more difficult.
By way of a preview, I would like this evening to try to articulate to the House some of the comments which I have received from constituents in conversations, correspondence and telephone calls, as a result of meetings which I have had in high schools within my constituency, as a result of conversations on the street, in my office, and as a result of public meetings in certain towns.
With reference to the latter, one of the most notable and I think most productive events with which I have been associated for a period of time was a visit to Hartney, which is in the heart of my constituency by the Hon. Jean Charest, Minister of the Environment. He came at the invitation of the community on an evening when it was approximately 30 degrees below zero. He spoke to some 250 people that evening and in my opinion he was exceedingly well received. There was a good opportunity for questions, for answers and for an exchange of views. It is the type of visit which should occur more frequently in the future.
It is important for members to come to us from the province of Quebec and it is important for members from western Canada to go to the province of Quebec if we are to achieve the kind of understanding which we are seeking.
Almost without exception the people whom I speak to in my constituency want Canada to remain united. They say that first and foremost and sometimes with varying degrees of emotion. They are proud of Canada and they know that they have had very significant privileges in terms of living in Canada. They want that Canada to continue to exist.
However, having said that, many of my constituents then express some frustration, frustration with the fact that first of all many of them do not understand why there is such a debate today. I suppose they feel that way in part because they like what they see in Canada and they assume that others should feel the same way. I think that is particularly true of those who were not bom here but who have migrated here.
Second, many of them are frustrated with the fact that this debate in which we are now participating seems to have been occurring over and over again throughout recent memory. They are frustrated with our inability to resolve that debate. Quite frankly, many of them are impatient with the process, and as the previous speaker
February 6, 1992

has just said, they are exceedingly anxious that we reach a solution to our problems.
Some concerns are more specific than that. Some have a great deal of difficulty, Madam Speaker, as I think you would understand, with some of the language we have used during the course of the debate. If I were able to go back and choose our words differently than we have done in the past, I would wish that we could find two different words other than the words "distinct society", because those two words in particular have caused in my mind a considerable amount of misunderstanding throughout the land. I think in part that this is so because the word "distinct" in my mind in English means something different than it does in French.
To me, the word "distinct" implies difference. I have no difficulty as a Canadian and certainly as an historian in proving to my satisfaction and I hope often to others that there are very significant differences that have been a part of our history, differences which continue today. I think, for example, of the differences which exist with the Civil Code in the province of Quebec as established by the Quebec Act of 1774; I think of the differences in land forms as with seigneurialism as established in 1774, I think of the rights given to the French language in the courts and in the legislature as subsequently developed after 1791. In my mind, these differences which exist are a product of our history.
But perhaps to our shame many Canadians do not know our history, and certainly the history of all of our regions as well as I would wish that they do. Part of the difficulty we have when we come to the debate is, as many of my constituents say, "I want to keep Canada together, I want it to remain as it has been in the past, but I am exceedingly anxious that it be a Canada in which all are treated equitably and equally".
One of the difficulties with the proposals which we have before us is that they raise in some people's minds a suspicion that the Canada that would emerge would not be one which treats all equally and equitably. I think that is perhaps the most difficult task that is before us now. If I could find one magic solution which would help with the level of understanding which exists in my constituency, it would be the ability to demonstrate to all that the proposals we have before us are designed to recognize and to reaffirm certain differences which have existed in
The Constitution
the past, but that they do not propose to give special advantages to anyone in the future.
I have constituents who are concerned with respect to the debate between what they perceive to be collective rights and individual rights as protected under the charter. I have constituents who are concerned about the proposal for self-government for aboriginals because they do not understand exactly what we propose when we say that.
But it seems to me the lesson that comes through in all of this is that our task in 1992 and perhaps in 1993, or whenever this debate should end, is to listen more carefully to others than we have been doing in the past. We live in a very busy world. Canada exists in many ways in spite of its geography rather than because of it. There is an immense barrier created by distance within our land. One of the sadnesses of that is the fact that it is very difficult for many of us living in our regions to know those who live in other regions very well.
The task before us in 1992, and I hope as a by-product of this debate and the ensuing debates and discussions that will take place during the course of the summer, is that we will seize upon the opportunity whenever it arises to listen carefully so that we can understand exactly what others are saying. Unfortunately this lack of understanding has troubled us immensely. In my part of the world people ask and continue to ask that often repeated question which I know the residents of Quebec no longer want to hear. What does Quebec want?
When I have had occasion to visit the province of Quebec and to speak with residents, they say in return: "Exactly what is the opinion in the west that makes some people there feel as they do toward us?"
Sometimes I feel that we simply have failed to learn to know each other very well. We have failed to learn to understand each other. What is required is that people in different regions should sit down and listen as carefully as they can to what is being said. For example, after the right hon. Joe Clark spoke at a meeting in Brandon, a constituent came to me and said, with some sadness in his voice, that it was a wonderful speech, he thought he understood the proposals much better than he had before, but he said: "I do not think we can give Parizeau and the Parti Quebecois what they want; I do not think we can give the separatists what they want".

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
In return, I said to him that I thought that was a very important statement on his part because it demonstrated that there was still a lack of understanding in the sense that we are not trying to give the separatists what they want. Because, Madam Speaker, I think you would agree that there are some in each of our regions who are not anxious to find a solution. They are not anxious that we should find a consensus upon which we can build.
Our task is to find some sort of middle ground. That is what these proposals are all about. I think it is what my constituents would want us to do and what they believe we can do, find the middle ground so that we can build in the future the same way we built in the past. Then we could have a united Canada of which we are all proud and where people are able to grow and enjoy the benefits while, at the same time being satisfied that the needs of a broad majority of Canadians are being met.
Our task is to listen more carefully during the next few months than we have ever done before. I am convinced if we can do that we can resolve our differences and can ensure that our children and our grandchildren have the opportunities to live in the same united Canada that many of us, regretfully perhaps, have all too often taken for granted.

Madam Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to discuss at some length the constitutional issues that face this country.
On November 7 the special joint committee on a renewed Canada was scheduled to hold hearings in Thunder Bay. Unfortunately, on July 6 the committee was recalled to Ottawa where they restructured themselves. As a result, the riding I represent, Thunder Bay-Nipigon, was not given the opportunity to make its representations to the special joint committee. We had already established some groups that were interested in making those submissions. As a result, on December 9 we undertook in our riding to hold those hearings. They were held on that particular day through the courtesy and through the help of the Thunder Bay Multicultural Association which kindly donated its hall. We had 31 individuals and groups who presented their thoughts on the future of this Canada of ours. We had people who
were able to translate into French, Ukrainian, Polish, Finnish, Russian, Italian and Portuguese; all provided these services voluntarily.
At the hearings that day the people who were involved in making the presentations developed a synthesis or a summary of what we heard during those 13 hours of hearings and I would like to present those findings to the House. I think I can summarize and break it down into four areas.
We talked at some length, as you would guess, about the distinct society, the linguistic issues that face us in this country, multiculturalism and a general catch-all of other issues that some people were concerned about. Let me start out by giving you the consensus and a summaiy of the briefs that we heard that day. First, Shaping Canada's Future Together, the document from which all the groups worked, the consensus was that the document itself added confusion to the debate. Terms that were used in that document were not defined properly. The document was complicated and if most Canadians are to understand it, it should be simplified and out of that came the consensus that there were too many demands for community rights and the Constitution should give greater emphasis to individual rights.
There was also a consensus that the present government has no mandate for Canadians to change the Constitution unilaterally and therefore a national referendum is mandatory before any change is made to the present Constitution. We then went to the linguistic duality issue, bilingualism in Canada. In 31 presentations there were those who thought that Canada should have only one language and those who supported to the fullest extent the official bilingualism policy of our country.
If there was one consensus, particularly from students, it was that all Canadians should learn more than one language but it should not be a forced situation. It is well known that the vast majority of Canadians want a review, not only of bilingualism but of the applications of bilingualism.
I thought these were very interesting comments with respect to the distinct society. We come from the centre of Canada where the east ends and the west begins. The consensus we heard is that Quebec is already distinct because of its language, culture and civil code. These
February 6, 1992

areas should always be retained. Any additional powers must be given to all provinces.
My friend John Wreszchak of the Polish Society of Thunder Bay made an interesting comment. He said: "Canada has blossomed because Quebec is distinct. Quebec has something we should all be jealous of".
The students of St. Ignatius High School said: "Canada will not survive without Quebec. Quebec needs to preserve its right to be different".
The students of Hillcrest High School said: "We feel that giving Quebec control over their cultural rights is a good idea, but further special powers are unacceptable".
Sam Frederico, president of the Italian Society of Thunder Bay, said: "We are all distinct societies. We all have our birthright, customs, religion, language, which are the makeup of our various cultures and heritage. This is the miracle we call Canada".
Those were some general comments on the distinct society clause.
Quebec's distinctiveness should be recognized. The citizens of Quebec are different because of their language, customs and heritage. They have the right to these customs. If they feel insecure and want these rights enshrined in the Constitution, there should be no doubt that they should be enshrined.
Those are interesting comments from the people in the centre of Canada about the distinct society clause we have heard so much about.
There was an interesting consensus with respect to multiculturalism. More than one-third of Canada's population today is a direct result of people who chose Canada as their home and have become Canadian citizens. Many have retained their culture and their heritage, but first and foremost they are all Canadians and immensely proud to be Canadians. Canada is now their homeland. Everything else is secondary.
One comment was: "Immigrants must make the culture of their homeland secondary and multiculturalism should not be enshrined. We grew up in a multinational country and all it created was jealousy and racism. People came here not to stay what they were. They came to Canada to become Canadians".
The Constitution
The students of Hillcrest High School said: "We feel that multiculturalism must take place within the framework of being Canadian. The country would be more united if we were all Canadian first, followed by our nationality of descent. Different cultures should have the right to retain their customs but they should be Canadian first".
John Wreszckak said: "Canada is a family. The parents should treat all members of the family equally for the family to thrive. If one child is favoured the family becomes dysfunctional and it turns against itself".
Glen Bagdon, a member of the Lithuanian community said: "Coming to Canada was a test of one's faith. We hoped for better days and hoped one day we would become Canadian. We kept our customs but we were Canadian first". They go on and on.
Rita Ubriaco, another participant, said: "We all have various cultures but in Canada, as in many other countries, we have the British tradition-parliamentary democracy and the rule of law-and that is why we came to Canada".
There were other constitutional issues discussed concerning other rights. We heard that property rights should be enshrined in the Constitution.
Many of our citizens, especially our seniors, who made representations that day said that the health care system is in jeopardy and the separation of a province from Canada would further jeopardize the delivery of our health care system. They said that the Senate is not effective in its present form, yet not enough information is available for its restructuring. Free trade should be implemented between all provinces. Elected members of Parliament should express the views of their constituents first and foremost. There should be more free votes in the House of Commons. If individual rights are enshrined the Constitution does not need a social charter.
Those were the topics that were discussed throughout the day. If I could summarize with one comment, which is at the bottom of the submission: Canadians must succeed. We need a strong federal government and we need a strong united Canada. Our Canada includes Quebec.

February 6, 1992
The Constitution

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is a valuable debate. It is an unusual debate because it is one that focuses entirely upon what we are hearing from our constituents on the subject of the Constitution and what we ourselves, as members of Parliament, are prepared to do; we who will be charged over the next few weeks and months with shaping that new Constitution.
Like my colleagues, I have had a series of meetings in my constituency on these subjects and have been conducting surveys of my constituents. I will very briefly summarize what I have been hearing.
My constituents rank Senate reform as their highest priority. In the 10 years of its existence, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms has become very important to my constituents. In fact, they were not supportive of the ability of governments to override the charter using the notwithstanding clause. At the same time, most of them indicated that they did not want to see the charter extended, except perhaps to include an environmental rights clause.
The majority of respondents to my queries would like to see the process for public involvement in constitutional amendments strengthened, primarily through referenda and public hearings.
Many of my correspondents do not think that multicul-turalism should be reflected in the Constitution as a principle of our society. Those same constituents were not aware that multiculturalism is now reflected in our Constitution as a principle of our society.
The concerns of aboriginal peoples were a high priority for my constituents, while they seemed to be split on the question of which jurisdiction should have control over language policy.
Finally, my constituents indicate to me that a strong federal government that can ensure Canada's international competitiveness and is able to set national standards but has strong regional representation is important to them.
It is my understanding that throughout our country many citizens' committees, many constituent assemblies have been set up to study the 28 proposals, comment on them and analyse them, and that representatives of those committees will be attending the joint committee on Canada's renewal next Monday. That is a laudable move and I look forward to meeting with some of the
people who will be coming to make their presentations. Some that I am aware of, and I know there are many others, are those from Sarnia-Lambton, York-Simcoe and Selkirk.
I think the joint committee is doing a great service to the process. I am delighted to see that it is proceeding without rancour in a spirit of multi-partisanship and attempting to do the best it can for Canada. It has a phenomenal chore in front of it. It is worth noting that these 30 individuals, members of the House of Commons and the Senate from all parties, are spending as much as 90 hours to 100 hours a week on their task. They are conducting hearings five days a week and are conscientiously attending the five constitutional conferences which are being held on the weekends.
It is a privilege to have played some role in this process, having had the challenge of co-chairing the previous joint committee on the constitutional amending process.
What we recommended in our report on June 20, 1991 was an open process. I am delighted that the process has been opened as it has. I am also pleased to note the role that Albertans are playing in the process. Canadians from all parts of the country are, but notably in Calgary we had an Alberta minister who is responsible for the dossier. We also had a former premier of our province co-chairing the conference sponsored by the Canada West Foundation.
The value of these conferences when the history of the time is written will be remarkable because they have brought a focus to the debate that may have been lacking before. The Calgary conference in particular, dealing with the council of the federation, rejected that idea overwhelmingly.
It approved, not surprisingly, an elected, effective and almost equal Senate; but it tossed us a curve as well. It said that there must be a voice for the voiceless in that Senate. It is an interesting challenge to think of a Senate which is territorial in its representation but which will have supplemental representation from aboriginals obviously, as was recommended in the government proposals, and perhaps from others. It will be a tremendous challenge to see how those others get selected.
Perhaps we could examine the Athenian model of actually choosing them by lottery. After all, some of the greatest contributions at the weekend conferences are being made by the lottery people, people who had
February 6, 1992

indicated an interest in the process, ordinary Canadians who were chosen by lottery.
I mentioned that I had a number of public meetings on the subject. Following one of those meetings, a constituent of mine bom in Holland, a Canadian citizen for many years, approached me and said: "Jim, I did not want to raise this during the meeting, but why should we give Quebec a distinct society?" My response was: "We should give them a distinct society for just the same reason that they should give us the Rocky Mountains". He said: "We have already got the Rocky Mountains". I said: "That is my point, George".
The second point he made was: "Why do we spend so much money on bilingualism?" I said: "You are from Holland. The Dutch spent a lot of money in turning back the sea. The Dutch could have walked away from that and gone to high ground and become Germans, but they didn't do so. What they did was they decided to fight back the sea and developed special national character traits as a result of that".
We have developed special character traits as a result of having a two language policy. We have developed the skill of compromise and accommodation and understanding the other person.
That brings me to my final point, which is that we must go beyond tolerance. We can tolerate black flies and mosquitoes. We can tolerate boils. We do not particularly like them, but in order to move genuinely from tolerance to mutual respect we have to get to know the other individual. As my colleague from Brandon-Souris said: "We truly do not know each other". We are a multitude of solitudes in this country.
We need as well to covenant with each other. Professor Donald Bailey of the University of Winnipeg was a witness before the previous joint committee on March 27 last year in Winnipeg. He said that what we are talking about is a contract in our Constitution. We ought to be talking about a covenant. In covenants the emphasis is on optimums, not minimums. The obligation is to seek ways of giving mutual sustenance as long as the other party has need, not only until the legal terms of the written agreement have been satisfied.
The Constitution
Beyond the covenant I think we ought to be grateful. The greatest gift according to Steindl-Rost is thanksgiving. In giving gifts we give what we can spare and in giving thanks we give ourselves. One who says thank you to another really says: "We belong together, giver and thanksgiver belong together". Let us be givers and thanksgivers as we go through this difficult process so that we may deserve to remain one united country.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to have the opportunity to stand in the House tonight to participate in this demonstration of the desire of Canadians to be part of this constitutional debate.
I was certainly pleased as all members of the House were when the agreement was reached to allow this opportunity for us to put before the House and before the Canadian people-and when I say that I mean all Canadians-the views of those people we represent. I say that they want to be part of this debate and they really deserve to be a big part of it since it is their Constitution we are dealing with.
In this respect I hosted two town hall meetings back in mid-November. They were very well attended. I again want to congratulate the people in Prince Edward- Hastings for their attendance. I have to admit I was very surprised at the number that did turn out. One particular meeting of those two was on a Friday night in a small town. I said to some of my staff as we went to that town: "If we have 20 or 25 people out tonight I will be very pleased". We had 78 people. One might say that is not a lot of people, but in a small town of less than 1,000 people that is a considerable number.
The only disappointment I did have was that I would liked to have had more young people at both of the meetings, more people of a younger age, so that we could have had more input from them. However those were the people who chose to come to the meeting.
At the meeting I did not offer any of my personal comments or interpretations, but we went over each of the 28 points of the constitutional proposal and asked them to fill out a questionnaire which they had received

The Constitution
on arrival so that if they did not wish to speak they could express their views. We tabulated those at the end.
Before I am finished I am going to run through those conclusions quickly. They may not necessarily be my own personal conclusions, but they are the conclusions of those who attended those meetings and asked me to bring their views forward. I can say as well that I have received dozens, hundreds, more than that, of telephone calls and letters. I am certainly impressed as all members are with some of the letters that are many typewritten pages long. That is indicative of the concern of many people of the constitutional debate we are going through at the present time.
I had the meetings in the way I did because I did not want to speak at them. By that I mean I wanted to hear what the constituents of Prince Edward-Hastings had to say. I can tell the House and all Canadians-and I am not tooting my own horn-that that is what many Canadians want from us as members of Parliament. If nothing more, they want us to listen and to pass that on. Again I appreciate that opportunity here tonight. They had many concerns and they had many questions. They want their feelings and representations considered in this important national debate.
As I say, I have received many letters. I have responded to those to the best of my ability. I have extended as much information to those people as I possibly could and I know they have appreciated it.
It may not be a surprise-and I am sure it is not-to those in the House and to those who are watching that the public has grown very cynical of elected politicians. Many times it has fallen upon myself and others here to field criticism and objection over our behaviour in the House. I have to admit that too often I had to agree with them. With an effort such as holding the town hall meetings I had an opportunity not to lecture, but to hear my constituents.
I may not use all my 10 minutes. I want to table these and it is my understanding that we can table them with the Clerk tonight. I would ask to do that when I am finished. I have forwarded them to the joint committee and have had letters of acceptance and recognition. I appreciate that as well.
I am going to go through the conclusions quickly. I want to say from the outset that I am not making excuses. I do not necessarily agree with all of them. I may
agree to different degrees with some of them. I can say that I know there are likely people in the House and people watching tonight who will be shocked and not be very happy with some of them, but the point of this session tonight is to hear what Canadians have to say.
The proposal on property rights is supported but considered too vague. These are referring to the 28 proposals. Although the override or notwithstanding clause was the object of considerable discussion by the participants, the consensus was that implementation should require a 60 per cent vote of Parliament or legislatures rather than a simple majority.
The distinct society is opposed by the majority along with any special status for Quebec. Aboriginal claims have the support of the majority but with some concerns about self-government and the period proposed to finalize any agreements. The Canada clause is favoured except for the items requiring governments to preserve language rights and Quebec's role in preserving and promoting distinct society.
People want more voice in government and more responsiveness from MPs. An elected Senate with regional representation gaining favour is supported with the Senate having significant powers. A majority opposed concurrent election of the Senate with the House of Commons. The proposed composition of the Supreme Court was not supported by the majority. Consensus on an amending formula for the Constitution favoured approval by two-thirds of the provinces and a referendum with a double majority. Unanimous approval and veto by any government or group was strongly opposed.
A majority approved the free movement of people, goods, services and capital, but the support for exclusive authority to lie with the federal government was marginal. Marginal opposition was expressed against opting out provisions. The harmonization of economic policies did not receive majority support. Questions respecting distribution of government powers were not strongly supported except for the strong opposition to the delegation to the provinces of responsibility for immigration and culture.
There was no significant opposition to eliminating the federal declaratory power. In general, people favour a strong central government. There is strong opposition to delegating powers to provinces unevenly. There is equal support and opposition concerning federal introduction

of cost-shared programs in provincial jurisdiction but strong opposition to any opting out of such programs.
There was extremely strong opposition to the council of Confederation. Many commented that there was already too much government.
I read those into the record and I repeat, I do not necessarily agree with all of them. Some of them I do agree with, some of them I do not. We do not have the time for me to discuss that and to put my views forward tonight.
However, I would like to agree with the previous speaker. We know-and if we do not, we have our heads hidden in the sand-these feelings and these concerns are out there. As I said at the start, some of these are very strong statements. I am sure there are members in the House tonight who will say: "There is part of the problem". We have to be realistic. Those are the views of some Canadians.
Let us hope and pray for the spirit of compromise, the spirit of understanding and the spirit of respect which I think is gaining ground. These meetings took place in mid-November. I was pleased with some who attended those meetings. When I saw them there I thought: Here are some very strong-minded, strong-willed, strongthinking people. At the conclusion of the meeting they thanked me for having it and said: "Lyle, I feel and think differently now than I did three hours ago".
I stress and urge all Canadians to attend any of these meetings, view all of these things, and go forward as we all need to and should in the spirit of compromise, understanding and respect for all other Canadians so that we can keep it together. Together we stand and divided-I don't know what the answer is and I don't really think it would be a good one.

Madam Speaker, I would like to begin my comments this evening by indicating that I have the most common culture as a Canadian sharing something with you tonight. I have the common cold.
So if I sound a little bit gruff and a little harsh it is very systemic and very Canadian to have one of those at this time of the year, unless you are among the more fortunate and go to Florida for the winter. But I don't
The Constitution
consider them quite as Canadian as we who stay here and work throughout the entire year and maybe play at Canada throughout the entire year. But a vacation is nice sometimes and sometimes I am envious that I do not take more of them in the nice south in the wintertime.
Although I am an elected member of Parliament I do not wish to speak on this subject so much as a member of Parliament, but as a Canadian and as a son of an immigrant who came to this country from Europe in 1929, and he thought for ever and a day that he was coming to one country, Canada.
So many other people who came to this country and made this country a strong, powerful nation, who built this country up into a modem society, they came to every province, they came to the east coast, they came in the earlier part mostly from Europe.
They came to the west in droves after the turn of the century and built up the west. They came to a Canada that they had read about as a promised land, as a place where they could make a living, raise a family and be away from the crowds and the disparity that occurred in some of the countries they lived in.
After 125 years, which we are now going to celebrate as a country, so many of these immigrants-and I am not talking about the founding nations so much in my report, although they also were very instrumental in putting this country together, knitting it together and creating the provinces-I am talking about my own particular family, where my father and mother came here in 1928 and they worked hard and they prospered and they raised a family which now lives in the province you are from, Madam Speaker, in your own constituency. I have a brother working and raising a family there-to the coast of British Columbia where I have a brother working.
We sons of immigrants grew up in this country because we were proud of it. It offered us opportunities. It offered us opportunities because it was diverse, it was large, it was rich, and it had many, many people with the desire to work hard and take that risk and leave home and start a new life.
My father celebrated his 90th birthday two weeks ago, and he is still quite strong and able, a little wrinkled maybe. He made a speech about this country and how danged foolish we would be to even think of dividing it. He worked hard and he is still living, together with my

The Constitution
mom, and as they get older they cannot perceive of this country being divided.
When you consider the hundreds of thousands of people who came to Canada, whether it was to Newfoundland, whether it was the province you are from, Madam Speaker, not coming from Quebec, but coming in fact from other places to start their lives there and having their offspring, their sons and daughters, moving from wherever in Canada, in some cases back to Quebec and adopting that province as their home province with its uniqueness and with its marvellous people, we have to ask the question: Where did this all begin, this desire to make our country two instead of one?
I blame the politicians. I believe it was politically driven, both from outside of Quebec and inside of Quebec. It was not so much from the grassroots. Who wants to divide this nation up? I believe it was politically driven and I believe we have to nip that in the bud right now.
The country, with successive Prime Ministers set about trying to find a way of accommodating that particular problem, as well as others we now face in western Canada of some alienation. I think they have a set of proposals of which I believe all will not be accepted. But there are enough good ones there that we collectively as a country can even become stronger.
The idea of electing a Senate is a terrific idea. I was just down in the United States in Washington and a senator told us that was the right way to go. He said that it would give our Senate some respect. I agree with that.
This appointment of senators is not what we should be doing. It was an old tradition that we brought back from England. Let us elect the senators, it makes sense. Let them be responsible to an electorate. I agree with that. Whether we will end up with a Triple-E or a one-and-a-half-E or a two-E, but I think we should have two Houses and I think that is the way we should govern ourselves. Let us decide collectively to do something like that.
I wonder why we are not sometimes looking at changing this House a little bit and making it more effective. Why do we have to go to the electorate whenever the Prime Minister calls an election as opposed to maybe
setting an election day every four years or five years? Maybe we could avoid some costly elections.
We may have some minority governments, we may have governments lose power, but why call an election, why not have the Governor General find a new government that would form with some other coalition? That does happen in other countries and it is really worth considering in my view.
Let us set the date. We all know when it will be coming. We cannot tamper around a lot with the dates as we are now. I wonder if that should not also be considered.
You hear a lot of people talk about why we should stick together. The best reason I can think of, as some I heard this evening and I am sure we are going to hear, it is the young people, it is the children, it is the next generation. Are we going to leave them a divided Canada?
Are the immigrants who came to this country, who wanted a strong nation, going to have to tell them we could not keep the place together when so many others are trying to do so, when so many countries are trying to find common ground, common markets, common currencies because it really is a way of expressing strength and peaceful co-existence. We do have a new world order, there is no doubt about it.
I am going to end on one more area that will keep this country strong, I believe, from coast to coast, and that is the economy. If we do not work on our economy, there may be more and more reason to say that this country is not working because of our differences and because the politicians have not worked in trying to give us a better standard of living.
Without a strong economy, we will find dissension always in this country. We do go through recessions from time to time. They will not stop because we may change governments. I think we have to harness them or at least adjust to them so that they do not become so deep, creating so much unemployment that in fact it creates nothing but dissension.
We have a great opportunity in this land. This country, I believe, is still regarded as the second best place in the world, if we follow the United Nations position on it.
February 6, 1992

I submit to you, Madam Speaker, that if we divide this nation, we will not be the second best place in the world; we might be the fifty-second or the seventy-seventh or whatever number, because people will see we have lost a great opportunity.

Madam Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to rise in the House during this special debate on the federal proposals. After listening to the speeches we have had so far, I must say I am disappointed in the level of this debate. It sounds more like a series of open-line shows than a serious debate, when in a matter of only a few weeks or months the final proposals on the constitutional future of this country are to be submitted to Quebec.
I listened more or less attentively to speeches similar to those made in 1980, with their references to this great and beautiful country of ours and their promises of major changes. Twelve years later, Madam Speaker, such speeches are no longer appropriate. In February 1992, they seem rather irrelevant. After all, when the House meets to discuss national unity, it cannot, in the process, ignore the Quebec question.
Quebec is the only reason national unity is a problem for the rest of Canada. This evening I heard about solutions to all kinds of problems, but no concrete proposals for meeting Quebec's aspirations. I realize now why, after the Quebec round, people wanted to drop the word Quebec and call this the Canada round.
After Meech Lake and the lack of generosity shown at the time by the rest of Canada, they now want to confuse the issue and dilute Quebec's aspirations in this vast, 28-proposal plan. However, Madam Speaker, in the end it always comes down to the co-existence of two founding peoples, and whether, in this institution and in this country, there is any possibility they would be able to get along and prosper together.
Madam Speaker, after Meech Lake, English Canada caught a new virus. It was afflicted with acute consultation, and for a year or rather 18 months after the demise of Meech Lake, we have seen a series of more or less useless consultations. Some were more useless than others, and we all remember the Spicer commission. We had the Beaudoin-Edwards committee, the Castonguay-Dobbie commission now Beaudoin-Dobbie and we have had a series of conferences. Basically, the process is still
The Constitution
going on. Unfortunately, we have become so obsessed by the process that we have forgotten the purpose, Madam Speaker. We are so intent on pleasing everyone and his dog that we have lost sight of the fundamental issues.
Consequently, when we as sovereignists listen to what is going on across the country and we see how the country is getting bogged down as a result, we can only predict that the process is doomed to fail. Madam Speaker, during the past few weeks, a series of conferences has rejected the federal proposals, one after another.
At the Halifax conference, for instance, the whole division of powers package was rejected out of hand. They opened the dictionary and came up with a new concept. To avoid the words "special status" they called it asymmetry, to confuse Canadians even more. Our pseudo-intellectuals thought they could sell this concept to the rest of the country. However, we have already had a reaction from Clyde Wells, one of the people who killed Meech Lake, and who saw through the mist of rhetoric and said that asymmetry was unacceptable in his Canada.
Madam Speaker, at the conference in Calgary, people also rejected most of the institutional reforms proposed by the government. As for the conference in Montreal, it might as well have been called off before it started, because all the proposals for economic union had already been rejected by members of the government. However, the charade goes on, Madam Speaker, and I predict that the Beaudoin-Dobbie report will be a carbon copy of the Charest report. The truth is, we have the same people around the table, the same parties with the same programs.
After the demise of Meech Lake, people still don't realize that talk and consult as we may, there are still two visions in this country. There are two visions that are diametrically opposed, whether we are talking about institutions, the division of powers or provincial jurisdiction. The problem, Madam Speaker, is that there are two visions and only one country. What we need is another country, and that is why Quebec sovereignists say to the rest of Canada: Make the kind of country you want. Make your own country. Concentrate all powers in Ottawa. Form an economic union that will turn your provincial governments into municipal governments. Go ahead, but don't expect us to get involved. We don't want to appear anti-Canadian. We realize some people may

The Constitution
prefer to live in a very centralized country, but we feel this goes against the initial pact of Confederation.
We can assume that English Canadians will develop their own kind of country and their own kind of institutions. We also have to recognize the fact that through the years, francophones and Quebecers have achieved greater maturity, both economically and culturally.
When I hear speeches that recognize our distinctiveness on the cultural level only, I must say that Quebecers' aspirations now go far beyond culture. We have also learned to use the economy to shape our present. We also want to control the instruments of our economic development. Therefore, Madam Speaker, when I see the process in which we are engaged, I must regret that we are talking at cross-purposes and that here in this House people still dream of the good old days and still talk about sharing the wealth, when this Parliament has got the country $400 billion in debt, when we know that every day the Minister of Finance makes decisions on the basis not of sharing the wealth but of sharing the debt.
I would like to be able to believe that the sharing of powers is not necessary at this time and that everything is going well in the best of all worlds. In reality, there is duplication every day; there is waste that our fellow citizens can no longer afford.
I would like to tell you that this debate is not artificial, but it is, Madam Speaker. The reality is that back in their ridings, some members mentioned the reactions of their constituents who do not want any special status for Quebec, who do not necessarily want any new power sharing, who want an equal Senate where Quebec would be equal to Prince Edward Island.
I know that some Canadians think that. They can make their country as they want to, Madam Speaker. But we are telling you tonight that the process this country is in does not fit reality and the last chance, Madam Speaker, was the Meech Lake accord. There are no more chances. The reality is that your process, the one being followed here, talks about the good old days. However, the people have matured much more than this Parliament. Madam Speaker, let us hope that we find a way to maintain the dialogue, to shape new institutions, perhaps common economic institutions, but be sure of one thing: Quebecers will decide their future themselves. This Parliament will not dictate to them what their future will be. Accordingly, Bill 150 of the National Assembly provides for a referendum on October 26 and I hope that this Parliament will respect the democratic choice of Quebecers.
