speechtext: Madam Speaker, on a night when we are discussing the new rules for the country of Canada and our relationships within the country I thought it would be appropriate for me, even though it is also contrary to our rules, to introduce to you-and I hope my friends will forgive me doing this-the 11th Ottawa Hunt Club B-Pack Cubs and B-Colony Beavers, who are with us studying rules.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. parliamentary secretary has very openly broken a rule which he knows very well. He also knows very well that the only person in this place who can openly recognize someone in the gallery is the Speaker. As someone who was in the scouting movement many, many years in her youth, I will join with the House and say hello to all of them.

Madam Speaker, I would like to thank my colleague, my friend who preceded me, because he spoke eloquently as someone looking at a picture of the past and in that picture he sees the future. I accept everything he says to us because he is talking about one vision of Canada. He says that we must save this country and build a country that is evolving. He reminds us that this country was created by a pact that resulted from negotiations between two founding peoples, yes, but their combined population was less than three million 125 years ago.
Today, Madam Speaker, the population is completely different. Our population is now over 27 million. My colleague, my friend, will be the first to admit that the population of the country he knew in the past is no longer the population he sees nostalgically, somewhat romantically, in that picture, some idealized dream of a past that never really existed. That said, I would not deny that there are legitimate aspirations, because every
February 6, 1992

people, all the peoples of Canada, have aspirations that must be considered in the future balance of this country. The history of Quebecers in North America and then in Canada is also my history. As a Canadian, when I was a young student, for me, the history of Canada was the history of Quebecers' experience, because for me they were Canadians. Like many recent arrivals to this country, I felt part of that experience.

It is an experience from which we have built our own Canadian experience. My hon. friend says that maybe this debate should have been one in which we start to talk about how to save this country.
I do not think there is a member in this House who would not want to save this country, like my constituents and the constituents of all members of this House. The questions have really become frustrating ones about how this is to be accomplished. Even worse, it is a perplexing one: What kind of country do we see?
My colleague from the Bloc has given his image of a country. I am not sure it is an image which is shared by all he would pretend to represent, although it is a legitimate position nonetheless. I also represent a sizeable section of this country which not only has deep roots in the geography, tradition and heritage that is Canada, that is Quebec, that is every other province but has a stake in the future and aspirations of all Canadians, whether they define themselves as-

Quebecers, Ontarians or British Columbians- [English]
they are part of something which we all aspire to build, because, as my colleague said-

we want to make a country in our image.

If we want to construct a country, what kind of an image is that? It is a country in evolution which takes into consideration that more than 40 per cent of the
The Constitution
people of this country have their roots in a history neither anglophone nor francophone in origin.
They see themselves as proud proprietors of the destiny of this country as much as anyone else. The key point that we should be concentrating on in this debate, in the discussion of the proposals that will eventually come before this House, is whether all Canadians will have proprietorship in the proposals this House must consider.
Until this point we have not reached that kind of consideration. As my colleague has said, we have taken a picture of the past seen with great nostalgia and inferred on that picture attributes which perhaps were not considered then and which we wish to selectively attribute through our historical interpretation. Whether we come from one side of that picture or the other we are excluding better than one-third of this country.
Most important, we are excluding the aspirations and the perceptions of the great majority of Canadians. They are beginning to suffer frustration and anguish upon seeing the growing intolerance which I see as a member of Parliament.
I, too, like some of my other colleagues, have sent out questionnaires. I have sought out opinions. Unfortunately, most of the results say that this country is a uniform, monolithic, homogeneous concept which coincides with the writers' own. I do not fit in that definition either, and I could see how my colleague from the Bloc would also not fit into it.
We have a higher calling in this House. I, and my colleagues from all parties, have a calling to ensure that we gather all of those ideas together and demonstrate some leadership. We cannot afford to marginalize those who saw this country as an opportunity to develop a nation built by working collectively, in collaboration, by ongoing co-operation and ongoing negotiations in which the key words were evolution and growth.
Maturity develops when we have a rapport that is not exclusive and is not excluding. There was an article in Time earlier this week alluding to the concept of a multicultural America. I think it is also a very worthwhile concept for the Canadian experience. It is only when we begin to understand the true meaning of this

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
kind of a philosophy, this kind of a concept that we define multiculturalism, that we throw away very quickly with the same kind of disdain that many of our less tolerant Canadians view bilingualism or a multicultural experience or in fact any other kind of experience that is not their own and not particular to their parish.
What we have to do with the debate that has begun tonight is to consider very seriously where the initiatives of the government's proposals are going to take us as individuals, as citizens of this country. Let not any of us give attention to all of those who would wield power by trying to influence a decision based on jurisdictional interests.
Like my colleague, I too am tired of seeing a premier from this province or another province wax with all kinds of arrogance and with all kinds of righteousness on constitutional position and tear the country apart as a result. Positions should be discussed in this House. All of us have the obligation and the authority to do so.
Yes, we can draw upon many of our constituents. I too would like to table in this House at least five of the briefs that were presented at a constitutional piazza in my riding. Over the course of seven hours people from all walks of life, such as Dan Iannuzzi, a publisher of the magazine, Communita' Viva, spoke about some of the reforms of institutions of Canadian-Italian business associations, youth groups and other community groups as well, all of them with a stake in this country and all of them feeling left out, all of them saying: "We can support a new constitutional package if indeed one must be had. If not, we would like to have a stake in what is going to be the outcome". With that stake we also gain that proprietorship. With that proprietorship we can afford to give support. We can afford to talk about those things which are germane to each and every one of us on a day to day basis, the economy, the way that we relate to our parents, to our families and to all of our neighbours.
All of those things cannot be achieved unless we allow all Canadians to draw that picture that my colleague painted so eloquently a few short minutes ago. We can expand that picture to include the whole complexity of Canadian society and give it the philosophical requirement it needs to sustain continued growth. That sustenance cannot be found except through a concept that
recognizes equality, diversity, partnership, collaboration, co-operation and justice.
That concept is encapsulized in one word, "multiculturalism". It is not encapsulized in any other. Only under that concept can we permit the kinds of differences and kinds of distinctions and the kinds of authorities and jurisdictions at a legislative level to ensure the flow of the evolution of a development of a country in which we can all take part.

Quebecers, Canadians, everyone. Thank you.

Mr. Speaker, it is with a spirit of great optimism that I stand before my colleagues today to speak about the positive momentum and energy that is building around the government's constitutional reform process.
Recent developments lead me to believe the federal government's efforts to promote a dialogue on constitutional reform is clearly having positive results. Granted, our constitutional discussions have a long history. Within the last 13 years the federal government has embarked on no fewer than 15 reports on the Constitution: Pepin-Robarts, Donald Macdonald, and Keith Spicer to name just three.
Last September, my government tabled its 28 proposals in the document Shaping Canada's Future Together. The process to make them known to Canadians across this great country is clearly galvanizing public interest and a desire to solve these issues for generations to come.
In the past weeks Canadians' well-known tolerance and respect for diversity have been diligently applied to the process of building a new Canada. Through the process that has been put in place, namely a special joint committee, the five national constitutional conferences, and the parallel process on the aboriginals, many opinions, some strongly stated, some passionately held, are being advanced. The constitutional conferences are providing Canadians with a first-hand look at how complex nation-building is in reality.
I would venture to say that there appears to have been a subtle change in the atmosphere toward the broad constitutional issue since Christmas. By this I mean that
February 6, 1992

there is more confidence that the process itself is working.
Canadians recognize that it has a much broader legitimacy and so it is a catalyst to inspire better ideas for achieving benefits for all Canadians.
Clearly the constitutional conferences have helped. This is due in part to the fact that Canadians from a wide variety of backgrounds have come together and somehow there is a greater sense that the country is at risk, that we risk losing something truly wonderful.
Canadians at these conferences are taking a national perspective on these issues, which is most heartening. All this is not to say that there will not still be sharp debate in our future. There is a lot to talk about and a lot of agreement still to seek, but this vigorous debate is providing many excellent ideas which will be very helpful in making improvements to the original package.
Let me detail for you some of these positive signs. The spirit of openness and diversity of opinion has marked all three conferences held to date, but participants at the first one are still talking about the spirit of Halifax. At this first conference the unexpected happened. Delegates demonstrated first hand to the rest of the country that they were open to accommodation to ensure that Quebec remains a member of the Canadian family. They were even prepared to suggest that the federal government should change its power-sharing arrangements, that such an act of accommodation would be made to ensure that Quebec is kept as a member of the Canadian family. Canadians have spoken and my government will listen.
Delegates to the conference in Calgary spent the bulk of their time talking about the Triple-E concept, a Senate that is elected, effective, and equal. As you may know there was overwhelming agreement on the first E, that the Senate ought to be elected.
Most people thought a more effective Senate is also a good idea.
True, there was no real consensus on the third E, no agreement on whether each province should send an equal number of senators to Ottawa. My government is anxiously awaiting to see how the special joint committee deals with this issue.
The Constitution
Furthermore there are now a number of formulas on the table that may meet with broader acceptance, such as proportional representation.
At the economic union conference in Montreal there was a broad view that the Constitution should be brought up to date allowing freer trade in services, in capital and people, not simply goods. This is certainly something that the government believes is important. Although there was less agreement on our other economic proposals, we must separate the underlying principles to continue Canada's wealth and prosperity.
Some criticize the language of our precise proposals but fortunately there seems to be a growing acceptance that economic union powers can be expressed as acts of joint decision-making, not unilateral authority.
My government looks forward to the discussions this weekend on distinct society, the Canada clause and Canadian values at the fourth conference. Already in the past few months many Canadians have suggested that accepting Quebec's distinct society would be the natural thing to do.
The future of Quebec in this country is a question to be addressed by every Canadian. When one-quarter of our population wonders if it is wanted, then that is a problem to all of us.
Canadians will voice their opinion on the need to reflect in our Constitution the reality that Quebec is a distinct society so that the French-speaking majority of Quebec can feel at home finally and forever in the Canadian family. The government will listen carefully to those views.
On the aboriginal proposals there seems to be a growing willingness in many quarters to describe the aboriginal right of self-government as inherent, as long as this is in the context of Canadian law or Confederation.
As you can see there is a momentum building. The mood is more buoyant and more positive. This bodes well for the country.
Almost as important as the conference subject matter is the tone with which it is discussed. It is particularly important at this sensitive time in our country's development that these discussions be characterized by a recog-

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
nition that compromise and accommodation are the essential ingredients for a united Canada.
That is exactly what has occurred in the last three conferences. Canadians are to be commended for their level-headed yet passionate approach to the process of nation-building. It is a process that is working extremely well. It is demonstrating that Canadians are seeking to understand one another's point of view in the interests of building a more united Canada.
As the joint parliamentary committee prepares its report for February 28, a report based on presentations by many different groups as well as the advice from the constitutional conferences, the process for a consensus has gradually begun to take form. Very shortly the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee will provide its recommendations to the government. Regardless of the direction of these recommendations, I am pleased to see that an openness of spirit is growing across the country. Now more than ever, as we enter the final stretch of this stage of the constitutional reform process, the ability of all parties to compromise, to conciliate and to achieve consensus will be paramount. The government intends to continue this open consultation process.
As the Prime Minister recently said: "We will remain flexible, open-minded and focused on an achievable consensus that can serve durably for generations to come".
The federal government looks forward to continued, vigorous and reasoned debate to ensure that the best possible constitutional package is achieved in this Canada round. It is clear from the spirit of compromise that Canadians want to keep this country united and prosperous. My government intends to do everything in its power to achieve that goal.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity this evening to say a few words about the unity of our country. I do so as the member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, but also as a citizen of this country, bom in Quebec, who chose Ontario as his province of residence.
Mr. Speaker, the electoral district in Ontario which I represent has a francophone majority, which is rather unusual and practically unheard of for some Canadians, and I would even say for some Quebecers. I have travelled many times in Quebec with my family, and I remember one trip in particular. I stopped at a service station near Quebec City, and the young man who filled my tank spoke to me in English. I answered in French, but he kept answering in English. He thought I would
appreciate that being from Ontario and as far as he was concerned, I was an anglophone. I had a hard time explaining to him that in Ontario like anywhere else, francophones speak French.
But the young man was English.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
No he was not. The hon. member for Hull-Aylmer said the boy was English. He was not and I am sure if the hon. member had heard him, he would have realized that. No, this was a francophone who was trying to do me a favour by talking to me in English.
My point is, Mr. Speaker, that first of all, this young man was not aware of the existence of franco-Ontarians, and what is even more important, I think, is that he was being friendly and wanted to please someone by speaking what he assumed to be his language.
And that is something we ought to remember. Every time Canadians quarrel about language, we forget there are many other Canadians with similar differences. The exception does not prove the rule, it is the rule, and we should remember that.
Mr. Speaker, Longueuil township is in my riding, and formerly it was the seigniory of Longueuil. This was before the Constitution Act of 1791, which separated- this may interest the hon. member for Shefford-Ontario from Quebec. The Act of Union of 1840 united Ontario and Quebec, and we have had a united Canada since that time, and I hope we will for many years to come.
Mr. Speaker last fall, I sent my constituents a questionnaire asking them for their views on the constitutional question. I now have the results, and I sent a copy to all the members of the parliamentary committee responsible for examining these issues. In fact, I sent copies to several members and to all the media in my riding, as well as to the respondents themselves. About 500 people returned the questionnaire, and here are their responses to some of those questions. I would like to share this with you.
The first question was: Do you think a constitutional declaration on the nature of Canada should include our commitment to two official languages? Ninety-two per cent of my constituents answered yes, 11 per cent said no, and 7 per cent were undecided or did not reply.

February 6, 1992

The diversity of our cultural heritage? Sixty-eight per cent answered yes, 15 per cent, no, and 17 per cent, other.
The distinctiveness of Quebec's society? Forty-two per cent answered yes, 41 per cent no, and 17 per cent had no opinion. Here again, the majority of my constituents were in favour of the proposal.
Recognition of the role of aboriginal people? Sixty-two per cent answered yes, 20 per cent, no, and 18 per cent had no opinion.
Actually, the response to all my questions was rather interesting. Thke, for instance, the mobility of goods and capital in Canada. Eighty-eight per cent in favour, 5 per cent opposed, and 7 per cent no opinion or undecided.
Elimination of the provinces' preferential procurement policies? Sixty-four per cent in favour, 14 per cent opposed, and 22 per cent other.
Elimination of interprovincial barriers to trade? Sixty-eight per cent in favour, 13 per cent opposed, and 19 per cent no response.
Elimination of provincial restrictions on the practice of certain professions? Seventy-one per cent in favour, 17 per cent opposed, and 22 per cent undecided.
The answers are not surprising, Mr. Speaker, because in a border region like mine, people are aware of the problems involved in moving goods or services between provinces.
Canadians may recall the story of the contractor in Nepean, here in the Ottawa area, who had been awarded a contract to install pavement in the Aylmer area. When it was found the bricks had been manufactured in Ontario, every single brick had to be removed.
Most Canadians know the story. What is not generally known, however, is the fact that the same has often happened in reverse.
I remember that when I was a provincial member, the Ontario government purchased railway cars from Hawker Siddeley in Thunder Bay instead of from Bombardier in Montreal, although they were more expensive, because it meant keeping the jobs in the province. Of course, the people of Ontario ended up paying more,
The Constitution
because the government had spent more money than was strictly necessary.
My constituents and I feel the kind of restrictive practices that exist today should be eliminated as far as interprovincial trade is concerned. Interprovincial trade in Canada should be increased. We should have free trade among Canadians.
I also asked some questions about an elected Senate. Eighty-one per cent said they were in favour of an elected Senate 12 per cent were opposed, and 7 per cent had no opinion.
Since I left a space for comments, I expected a lot of people to say we should get rid of the Senate or something like that. However, no one did. People were either in favour or opposed or had no opinion, but 81 per cent of the respondents said they were in favour of an elected Senate.
I also asked the following question: Do you think that the decision to create a new province in Yukon or the Northwest Tferritories should be up to the federal government and the ten provinces? Twenty-five per cent. The federal government and seven provinces? Twenty-two per cent. The federal government and the people of the territory in question? Fifty-one per cent. Only two per cent had no opinion.
Should the provinces be involved in appointing judges to the Supreme Court? Sixty-three per cent said yes and 25 per cent said no.
Mr. Speaker, I took this opportunity to tell you about the views of my constituents. I would also like to ask the Clerk of the House to lay the document on the table, and I am referring to the response of my constituents to the questionnaire.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the opportunity to participate in this very important debate.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity this evening to participate in this very crucial debate on the future of our country, a debate on whether or not we shall continue as a strong and united nation or whether we will allow, inadvertently or otherwise, Quebec to separate from the rest of Canada.

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
If we are to approach this issue in a realistic and unemotional way, it is important for all of us, whether we live in or outside Quebec, to understand fully the impact and the consequences that separation will have on our lives and on the lives of our families, our neighbours and our friends.
Separation would mean a lower standard of living for all of us. Canadians are bound together not only by a national government, by national programs and national institutions, but also by an interdependent national economy. Separation means severing not only our political ties but our economic ties as well.
In spite of our many provincial trade barriers, six provinces-Quebec, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta-trade more within Canada than they export to foreign countries. All provinces, with the exception of British Columbia, export significant amounts to Quebec. Of our three largest manufacturing provinces-Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia-only Quebec is more dependent on trade with other provinces than on foreign trade.
Quebec's manufacturing shipments are roughly split between international markets and the rest of Canada. In 1989, 14.5 per cent of Quebec's manufacturing shipments went to Ontario while only 5.9 per cent of Ontario's went to Quebec.
However, in terms of dollars, as opposed to percentages, Ontario sends $10 billion of its manufactured goods to Quebec while Quebec sends over $12 billion to Ontario. Quebec's independence would disrupt those economic ties and could result in the erection of tariffs and other trade barriers.
Separation would create two new countries, each with a smaller population and a smaller economic base than a united Canada. Smaller markets and smaller economies are greater risks for investors. Credit ratings would go down and borrowing costs would go up.
The result would be a rise in taxes or a drop in government services for everyone. Because it did not sign the Canada-United States Free Trade Agreement, an independent Quebec would have to negotiate its own trade agreement with the United States.
In return for such an agreement, the United States would undoubtedly want, among other things, the elimination of all restrictions on American ownership of Quebec businesses, the unlimited right for Americans to bid on Quebec government contracts and the right to buy Quebec power at Quebec domestic prices.
In addition, since Canada without Quebec would
represent only 75 per cent of its previous size, the United States might very well also decide to terminate not only the free trade agreement, but the auto pact as well.
Quebec's independence would also necessitate a division of Canada's assets and national debt. Some say, based on population, Quebec should assume 25 per cent of the national debt. Others say it should be 18.5 per cent based on Quebec's proportion of gross domestic product.
Without the consent of our creditors, the bondholders, Quebec cannot legally assume any of the national debt. At best, we can make a side deal where Quebec makes payments to Canada for whatever share of the interest and the capital we agree on.
However, if an independent Quebec, because of economic problems, defaults on its payments, the new Canada representing 75 per cent of the old Canada would still be responsible for the repayment of 100 per cent of the present national debt. Anyway you cut it, separation means a lower standard of living for each and everyone of us.
Well, if separation is not in our best interest either individually or collectively, what kind of a Canada do we need? In my view, we need a Canada with a strong national government and we do not need more decentralization.
Supporters of decentralization say that we are overgoverned, that we need to disentangle federal, provincial, regional and local jurisdictions and that we need to get decision-making closer to the people. By doing so, they say, we are going to eliminate duplication, waste and inefficiency.
That all makes good sense, but if we do decentralize, what will happen to national standards? What will happen to our national social safety net? What will happen to the equality of all Canadians and what will happen to our sense of being a Canadian? What do you think, Mr. Speaker, will our taxes really go down?
February 6, 1992

Well, if we do decentralize, the provinces will certainly need additional taxing powers to pay for their new added responsibilities. If we increase provincial taxing powers, we will have to decrease federal taxing powers. That in turn will reduce the number of tools available to our national government for managing the economy and creating an economic climate that encourages job creation and promotes price stability.
Canada is already one of the most decentralized countries in the world. The national governments of the United States and Australia both raise and spend substantially more money in comparison to their state governments than we do in comparison to our provincial governments.
Only Switzerland is more decentralized than Canada. The Swiss manage their economy by expelling foreign workers when unemployment goes up. In Canada this approach would be controversial, to say the very least.
The greater the degree of decentralization, the greater the need for federal-provincial economic policy co-ordination, something which is very obviously lacking between the federal government and the Ontario provincial government during the past few years. While the federal government was trying to restrain spending, the Ontario government was substantially increasing its spending. This increased spending contributed to higher inflation, higher interest rates and a more severe recession.
In 1988 the federal government reduced its income taxes. However, the effect was completely neutralized when the Ontario government raised its provincial income taxes. Further increasing provincial taxing powers will only create more potential for even greater policy conflicts and could lead us into economic chaos. That is the reason for the federal proposals for an economic union.
I think it is significant that in 1977 the leader of the Parti Quebecois, Jacques Parizeau, said: "Because rather often in Canada we tend to talk of the abusive centralized powers of Ottawa, we tend to forget that in reality Canada is highly decentralized". Ten years earlier Mr. Parizeau had said: "Any further decentralization would lead to a fragmentation of decision-making powers that would be incompatible with any rational planning". In my opinion Canadians should take Mr. Parizeau's advice, on this issue at least.
The Constitution
What we do not need is more decentralization. We do not even need more decentralization combined with the concept of an economic union. What we need is a strong and united Canada and a strong and effective national government.
When our country was bom its architects, Sir John A. Macdonald and Sir George-Etienne Cartier, delivered a message. Macdonald said: "We are a great country and we shall become one of the greatest in the world if we preserve it. We shall sink into insignificance and into adversity if we suffer it to be broken". Cartier said: "Avant tout, soyons Canadiens", above all, let us be Canadians.
That is a message we should all take to heart. [Translation]

Mr. Speaker, for months now, I have listened to the unending constitutional debate in this country. Mr. Speaker, I see one and only one solution to the present problem: sovereignty for Quebec and sovereignty for English Canada.
Mr. Speaker, I do not intend to return to the federal-provincial conference held in Victoria in 1971, where we all know that things broke down. In the 1980 referendum, I had the privilege to chair the "no" committee on the Quebec side of the Ottawa Valley. We wanted to try to find ways to unite this country and foster understanding from coast to coast. Mr. Speaker, this was followed by the unilateral repatriation of the Constitution in 1982 which left Quebec out.
In 1985, Mr. Speaker, the Liberal Party of Quebec under Premier Robert Bourassa was elected. In the following months, there were meetings that in April 1987 led to the Meech Lake accord, which was ratified by the 11 first ministers, the federal government and the opposition parties. Every province had until June 23, 1990 to ratify this agreement. T\vo provinces, Manitoba and Newfoundland, opposed it. Mr. Speaker, it was the only chance to allow Quebec to enter the Canadian federation with honour and it was refused.
Since then, Mr. Speaker, there have been many commissions and committees. There was Beaudoin-Ed-wards on the amending formula; the Spicer Commission which cost Canadians some $25 million; the Castonguay-Dobbie committee was set up, but we know that Mr. Castonguay resigned because, as he confirmed last week in La Presse, it was going nowhere. This committee was

replaced by the one chaired by Senator Beaudoin and Mrs. Dobbie. There have been regional conferences in Halifax, in Calgary and last week, in Montreal. In a week, one will be held in Vancouver, British Columbia.
The three main parties in the House of Commons asked for tonight's debate. I am sorry that the attendance is so low, Mr. Speaker, only a few members. If we took a vote tonight, the Bloc Quebecois would almost have a majority in this House. That is disappointing, Mr. Speaker, in that-

Thank you for your comments, Mr. Speaker. To continue, we are discussing the seemingly insoluble constitutional problem tonight.
Previous speakers this evening have offered no solution, Mr. Speaker. They only admitted the failure of constitutional discussions to date. The Meech Lake accord was supposed to be the Quebec round so that Quebec could return to the Canadian federation.
Today, Mr. Speaker, with the Conservative government's 28 proposals, it is now the Canada Round which seeks to solve all the problems at one go, even though Quebec was not allowed to solve its problems honorably. For over 30 years in Quebec, since the quiet revolution- a former colleague of yours here, Jean Lesage, was a minister and was Premier of Quebec from 1960 to 1966. The theme of Jean Lesage's election campaign in 1960, Mr. Speaker, was "masters in our own house", masters of our destiny, with control over cultural, social and economic matters. We have been demanding that since 1960, Mr. Speaker. We are in 1992 and Quebec is now ready to take on its destiny, to look after its own affairs. For Quebec, looking after its own affairs is not to lower
itself or English Canada but to enable both to evolve quite naturally, each in their own sphere as they see fit.
Mr. Speaker, English Canada wants power centralized in Ottawa; Quebec wants power decentralized in Quebec. It is all that, Mr. Speaker. We have gone beyond language and culture; we are now dealing with the economy and powers. The best evidence is that the Parti Quebecois wants sovereignty for Quebec and an economic association with Ottawa. The Quebec Liberal Party at its convention last year adopted the Allaire report recommending that Quebec take back 22 powers but still leave a few powers in Ottawa. It is no longer a partisan political issue; it is a question of Quebecers' collective will to look after their own future. That is what it is all about, Mr. Speaker.
On some occasions, we have been called stupid here in this House by the Prime Minister, as my colleague from Shefford was. We asked for apologies but they were not forthcoming. We are sometimes sneered at because we represent the majority political option of Quebecers, who want sovereignty for themselves and Canada to go its own way, Mr. Speaker. We do not want to stop Canada from succeeding, but we do not want English Canada's views imposed on Quebec by Canada.
Mr. Speaker, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee is to submit its report by the end of February. This House will surely study it. The committee will surely make some recommendations and then the House will surely come to a consensus, as happened with the Meech Lake accord, and everything wall again be on the table.
Mr. Speaker, that does not work. In Quebec, we are tired of dealing with the Constitution. In Quebec, we want to deal with our political, social, cultural and economic future. We want to have the powers that will enable us to develop our regions. We are always under the absolute control of federal government policies, in the environment, vocational training and recently, education. In all these fields, nine provinces exercise control over one province.
Mr. Speaker, in conclusion, the only thing I want is to have the people of Quebec consulted next October on their future. The referendum should ask Quebecers a clear, precise, unambiguous question on sovereignty and they will decide. For the benefit of both English Canada

and Quebec, Mr. Speaker, we must from now on talk about something other than the Constitution. We must talk about jobs for our young people. We must talk about the economy, health and education. We must talk about something else because we are destroying ourselves.

Mr. Speaker, I remember a phrase-

In English, a song Je vous aime beaucoup; in English, Mr. Speaker, "I love you". I think that is sort of the basic message that the people of Alberta, the people of my constituency, would have for the people of Quebec.
If I understood enough German to use a similar phrase then I would do so in the Chamber The people in my constituency and the people in the west generally have those kinds of emotional feelings for their citizens of German descent or of Asian descent. We are a nation of people who for the most part came from somewhere. If we backtrack far enough in history there are certainly theories that even our aboriginal people came from other continents and other parts of the world. That is what Canada is.
In listening to my colleague across the way who has certainly come to a different conclusion about the future of this country, I think the people in my riding would say to him: "Be cautious". I guess my own personal history and sense of family says be cautious.
My father's family came from an Irish Protestant heritage and into the province of New Brunswick years ago. Some of them wandered west and some of us are into several generations in the west now. My mother's side of the family came from Irish Catholic and into the Kingston, Ontario area and some of them wandered west. Now those genes are into the later generation.
In the meantime those who stayed behind are killing, maiming and bombing on the basis of religious differences that endured through the decades and through the centuries. Yet, as Canadians we have been able to escape the negative parts of that kind of heritage and replace them with a sense of community and a sense of communion.
The Constitution
If there is a message that exists in my riding from all of the sources that are available to me as a member of Parliament to gather information and to bring it to this Chamber, it is the message that we are proud of this country. This is the finest country in the world. Geographically it is huge. It is immense with potential that lasts for decades and centuries into the future in terms of natural resources and opportunity for generations yet unborn.
Culturally we are perhaps even richer. It is almost impossible to believe that there is another nation on the face of the earth that can boast in its citizenry a language spoken that is not spoken by at least one Canadian.
On my block in the city of Calgary in my constituency, the heritage of the people on that very short block on both sides of the street is enormous: eastern European, Asian, African, South American, American and several generations into Canadian. All of those are on a single block.
When I hear my colleagues across the way arguing for the notion of separation, I say: Be cautious. They have not only a tiny view of the world, a view which is too small in terms of the opportunity system for their children, but they have a view that I think the world says is impossible.
The last large experiment with the notion that you can impose a culture, you can impose a language, you can impose a political structure, was the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the notion of imposition had it fall apart. It has come to the notion of a federation which we have had for 125 years. We got there 125 years ago and the notion of federation has taken us to at least the second highest standard of living in the world.
They want to take some six million or seven million people in a piece of geography in North America and say: "We can impose a culture, we can impose a language, we can impose a political structure, and it will work".
In the last 13 years I have acquired some capacity in the French language. I have acquired it in the province of Quebec. I have acquired it by spending a lot of weekends in immersion. I have travelled that province. I have stayed in auberges and people's homes and attempted to feel what it is like.

February 6, 1992
The Constitution
When we get out of the politician's world and in with the people it is a world like my world in Alberta. The people are the same. They want the same kinds of things. They have the same diversity. They do not just speak French and a minority speak English in the province of Quebec; they speak Swahili, Hungarian, German, and on and on and on.
The notion some narrow-minded people have from that province that they can impose a single culture and a single way of thinking on some kind of unified body is a notion fraught with danger, a notion that has within it, inherent in it, failure.
If they achieve some kind of vote on some kind of referendum that says that we will separate and break up the country, and they are to experiment with that, there will be chaos. When he stood in this Chamber and said: "English Canada's views on Quebec", I have news for him. He should travel west more often, he will find out that there is no English Canada's view of anything.
There is no such animal as English Canada. There is Canada with Germans, Hungarians, Chinese, Irish and Scots. There are all kinds of heritages. If you go and live a little while in Newfoundland, a little while in Alberta and a little while in northern B.C., there are differences. The message that comes through is that it is a countiy full of differences.
By working together the way we have for 125 years, we are much, much more than the sum of the individual parts. To lead a group of people with their own children, to produce a tiny, artificial, impossible world for those children is really not doing them any kind of a favour.
Canadians love this country. One of the opportunities that we have had in this Chamber tonight and will have next Monday, Tbesday and Thursday is the opportunity to table a document, make sure it gets to the committee, to put a few comments on the record, to make sure that they get to the committee.
I want to table one. I have had contact in all kinds of ways with all kinds of constituents and I did put out a questionnaire. Over 1,500 people replied to it. I would like to table it and perhaps leave the Chamber with one message.
Of all of the questions we asked about the kind of Canada that the people in my riding would like to see for the future, they were not unanimous on anything. That is the strength of this nation, that we are not unanimous on anything perhaps other than the love for this country.
If we wanted some principles, three stood out. That was effective regional representation, equal provincial status and economic efficiency. Over three quarters of the people in my riding said those were three basic principles for Constitution-making in Canada.
We are about 99 per cent of the way there on all three of those and I hope this exercise in the next few months will take us the remaining 1 per cent and we will have the kind of Constitution that joins us together, makes us all feel proud for another 125 years at least.
